text:
Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035

The global used cooking oil (UCO) market is projected to reach USD 17.18 billion by 2035, recording an absolute increase of USD 8.62 billion over the forecast period. The market is valued at USD 8.56 billion in 2025 and is set to rise at a CAGR of 7.2% during the assessment period.

The overall market size is expected to grow by nearly 2.0 times during the same period, supported by increasing biodiesel production mandates and growing circular economy adoption worldwide, driving demand for sustainable feedstock alternatives, waste-to-energy conversion technologies, and renewable fuel production across both developed and emerging markets.

Quick Stats for Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Value (2025): USD 8.56 billion

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Forecast Value (2035): USD 17.18 billion

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Forecast CAGR: 7.2%

Leading Application in Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market: Biodiesel Production (50%)

Key Growth Regions in Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market: Asia Pacific, North America, and Europe

Top Players in Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market: Darling Ingredients Inc., Baker Commodities Inc., Arrow Oils Ltd., Olleco, Waste Oil Recyclers, GRAND NATURAL INC., GREASECYCLE, Brocklesby, Oz Oils Pty. Ltd., Mahoney Environmental

Gowing application diversity in oleochemical manufacturing, animal feed production, and industrial lubricant formulations creates expanding opportunities for UCO collection infrastructure and specialized processing innovations. Rising environmental awareness in Asia Pacific nations, coupled with expanding waste oil collection networks through commercial establishments and municipal programs, further accelerate market penetration across diverse feedstock segments.

The growing global emphasis on carbon emission reduction and renewable energy targets, particularly in transportation fuel sectors, generates sustained demand for recycled cooking oil feedstock and sustainable aviation fuel precursors incorporating advanced collection logistics and quality certification systems.

Industrial research demonstrating measurable improvements in greenhouse gas reduction exceeding 80% compared to fossil fuels, proven feedstock availability, and cost competitiveness reinforces biofuel producer confidence in UCO utilization, while circular economy trends toward waste valorization expand addressable market opportunities beyond traditional waste disposal categories into valuable commodity feedstock applications.

Biodiesel producers and oleochemical manufacturers increasingly incorporate UCO into production processes, refining operations, and sustainable product portfolios, creating mainstream consumption channels that extend beyond basic waste management into sophisticated industrial feedstock environments.

However, inconsistent collection infrastructure in developing regions and quality variability concerns affecting feedstock specifications may pose challenges to market expansion. Regulatory complexity regarding waste oil classification and cross-border transportation restrictions in certain jurisdictions also influence supply chain efficiency, requiring collectors to develop diversified operational strategies catering to specific regulatory requirements across different geographical markets.

Competition from alternative waste feedstocks during volatile commodity price cycles and technical requirements for contamination removal and free fatty acid management may limit processing accessibility among smaller biodiesel producers in emerging regions with constrained capital availability for advanced pre-treatment systems and quality assurance infrastructure.

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Year-over-Year Forecast 2025 to 2035

Between 2025 and 2030, the used cooking oil market is projected to expand from USD 8.56 billion to USD 12.13 billion, resulting in a value increase of USD 3.57 billion, which represents 41.4% of the total forecast growth for the decade. This phase of development will be shaped by rising demand for renewable diesel feedstock and sustainable aviation fuel precursors, infrastructure expansion in commercial waste oil collection systems and aggregation networks, as well as expanding integration with biodiesel production facilities and oleochemical processing platforms. Companies are establishing competitive positions through investment in collection route optimization, feedstock quality management capabilities, and strategic market expansion across food service networks, industrial collection segments, and municipal waste programs.

From 2030 to 2035, the market is forecast to grow from USD 12.13 billion to USD 17.18 billion, adding another USD 5.05 billion, which constitutes 58.6% of the overall ten-year expansion. This period is expected to be characterized by the expansion of specialized UCO derivatives, including purified feedstock grades and certified sustainable feedstock classifications tailored for specific biodiesel and oleochemical applications, strategic collaborations between collection service providers and biofuel producers, and an enhanced focus on traceability systems and sustainability verification certifications. The growing emphasis on decarbonization pathways and renewable fuel standard compliance will drive demand for verified UCO feedstock solutions across diverse industrial applications.

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Key Takeaways

Metric Value Market Value (2025) USD 8.56 billion Market Forecast Value (2035) USD 17.18 billion Forecast CAGR (2025-2035) 7.2%

Why Does Renewable Fuel Demand Drive UCO Market Expansion?

The used cooking oil market grows by enabling biodiesel producers, renewable fuel manufacturers, and oleochemical processors to access sustainable feedstock alternatives that support production mandates while meeting environmental demand for waste-derived raw materials.

Industrial operations face mounting requirements to implement renewable feedstock sourcing strategies with verified sustainability credentials, with UCO feedstock typically providing superior carbon intensity scores and regulatory compliance essential for competitive operations in biofuel production and green chemistry sectors.

The renewable energy industry's need for diverse feedstock portfolios and consistent supply reliability creates demand for various UCO grades that can provide optimal conversion efficiency, maintain stable quality parameters across different collection sources, and ensure regulatory compliance without compromising process economics or sustainability standards.

Government initiatives promoting circular economy principles and renewable fuel deployment drive adoption in biodiesel refineries, sustainable aviation fuel facilities, and oleochemical manufacturing operations, where UCO utilization has a direct impact on carbon footprint reduction and sustainability performance outcomes.

The biofuel industry's growing focus on waste-based feedstock prioritization and low-carbon fuel production further expands market opportunities, with lifecycle analysis demonstrating measurable greenhouse gas reduction benefits through UCO-based biodiesel utilization, renewable identification number generation, and carbon credit qualification programs.

Collection infrastructure limitations affecting feedstock availability and technical requirements for contamination removal and moisture management may limit accessibility among smaller biodiesel producers and developing regions with underdeveloped waste oil recovery systems and feedstock aggregation infrastructure.

Segmental Analysis

The market is segmented by application, source, and region. By application, the market is divided into biodiesel production, oleochemicals, animal feed, and others. Based on source, the market is categorized into food service, household, and industrial. Regionally, the market spans North America, Europe, Asia Pacific, Latin America, and mea.

What makes Biodiesel Production the Dominant Application Segment?

The biodiesel production segment represents the dominant force in the used cooking oil market, capturing 50.0% of the total market share in 2025. This established application category encompasses solutions featuring renewable diesel manufacturing capabilities from transesterification and hydroprocessing operations, including first-generation biodiesel plants and renewable diesel refineries that enable sustainable fuel production and consistent quality standards across all biofuel manufacturing applications.

The biodiesel production segment's market leadership stems from its essential feedstock requirements, with UCO capable of meeting diverse fuel specification demands while maintaining high conversion yields and operational reliability across all refining environments.

Within the biodiesel production segment, transportation biodiesel formulations account for approximately 22.5% share, driven by road transportation fuel mandates and fleet decarbonization initiatives. Industrial biodiesel represents 16.0%, serving stationary power generation and industrial heating applications, while marine fuel biodiesel captures 11.5% through shipping industry decarbonization requirements.

The oleochemicals segment maintains a substantial 12.3% market share, serving manufacturers who require sustainable raw materials for soap production, surfactant formulation, and specialty chemical applications. This application offers renewable feedstock alternatives for personal care and industrial chemical manufacturing while providing sufficient versatility capabilities to meet product performance demands and sustainability certification requirements. Within the oleochemicals segment, soap manufacturing accounts for approximately 4.8% share, surfactants represent 4.0%, and lubricants & greases capture 3.5% through industrial and automotive applications.

Other significant application segments include animal feed production utilizing processed UCO as energy-dense feed ingredients, and miscellaneous industrial applications serving specialized requirements. These diverse applications collectively represent the remaining market share, serving niche industrial protocols and specialized conversion processes.

Key advantages driving the biodiesel production segment include:

Established refining infrastructure with integrated feedstock pre-treatment operations that ensure consistent fuel quality production and specification compliance

High conversion efficiency capabilities allowing maximum diesel yield from waste feedstock without significant processing complexity

Proven regulatory compatibility, delivering renewable fuel credits and carbon intensity advantages while maintaining cost competitiveness against virgin vegetable oils

Broad market acceptance enabling straightforward blending integration and fuel distribution across existing petroleum infrastructure

How does Food Service Lead Source Category Market Share?

Food service dominates the source segment with approximately 58.4% market share in 2025, reflecting the critical role of commercial kitchen operations and restaurant networks in supporting global UCO generation and collection infrastructure worldwide. The food service segment's market leadership is reinforced by concentrated waste oil generation patterns, established collection service relationships, and rising participation rates across restaurant chains, hotel operations, and quick-service establishments in developed and emerging markets.

Within the food service segment, restaurants account for approximately 28.0% share, driven by high cooking oil utilization rates and frequent oil replacement cycles. Hotels represent 18.4% through centralized kitchen operations and food service facilities, while cloud kitchens & QSRs capture 12.0% through emerging delivery-focused food service models.

The household segment represents a significant source category through residential cooking oil disposal and municipal collection programs. This segment benefits from growing consumer environmental awareness that drives participation in waste oil recycling initiatives, municipal drop-off programs, and community collection events in environmentally conscious regions. The industrial segment serves food processing facilities, snack food manufacturers, and other commercial food production operations generating substantial waste cooking oil volumes through continuous manufacturing processes.

Key market dynamics supporting source segment growth include:

Food service sector expansion driven by urbanization and dining-out trends, generating concentrated UCO volumes in metropolitan areas

Collection service modernization enabling efficient routing optimization and quality management protocols

Integration of digital tracking systems facilitating traceability and sustainability documentation

Growing emphasis on comprehensive waste management driving demand for complete collection coverage solutions

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market?

The market is driven by three concrete demand factors tied to sustainability mandates and circular economy adoption. First, increasing renewable fuel mandates globally create growing demand for waste-based feedstock alternatives, with biodiesel blending requirements expanding by 5-8% annually in major economies requiring comprehensive UCO supply infrastructure. Second, government incentives promoting waste valorization and circular economy principles drive increased collection participation rates, with many countries implementing extended producer responsibility frameworks and waste diversion targets for organic waste streams by 2030. Third, technological advancements in feedstock pre-treatment and conversion processes enable more effective UCO utilization that reduces processing costs while improving biodiesel yield and quality specifications across diverse refining configurations.

Market restraints include inconsistent collection infrastructure across different regions that can limit feedstock availability and supply reliability, particularly in developing markets where commercial collection services remain underdeveloped. Quality variability and contamination concerns pose another significant challenge, as UCO feedstock requires extensive testing and pre-treatment to meet biodiesel specifications, potentially causing increased processing costs and yield losses. Competition from alternative waste feedstocks including animal fats and vegetable oil processing residues creates additional market dynamics affecting pricing, demanding strategic feedstock sourcing and blending optimization programs.

Key trends indicate accelerated collection infrastructure development in Asia Pacific markets, particularly India and China, where rapid urbanization and food service expansion drive substantial UCO generation growth. Technology integration trends toward blockchain-based traceability systems with digital collection documentation, automated quality testing protocols, and integrated supply chain management platforms enable transparent feedstock verification approaches that optimize sustainability certification and regulatory compliance capabilities. However, the market thesis could face disruption if significant advances in synthetic biology enable cost-competitive production of drop-in biofuels from alternative feedstocks or major policy changes reduce renewable fuel mandates across key biodiesel markets.

Analysis of the Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market by Key Countries

Country CAGR (2025 to 2035) India 8.4% China 8.1% usa 7.6% Germany 7.2% Japan 6.4% Brazil 6.1% Australia 5.8%

The used cooking oil market is expanding rapidly, with India leading at an 8.4% CAGR through 2035, driven by rapid food service expansion supporting substantial UCO generation growth. China follows at 8.1%, supported by high UCO generation from dense urban markets and growing collection infrastructure. USA posts 7.6%, anchored by strong biodiesel processing infrastructure and renewable fuel standard compliance.

Germany grows at 7.2%, with advanced waste oil regulation and comprehensive collection systems. Japan records 6.4%, reflecting high recycling adoption and environmental compliance culture. Brazil advances at 6.1%, emphasizing expansion of biofuel policies and sugarcane biodiesel integration, while Australia grows steadily at 5.8%, focusing on growing sustainability compliance and renewable fuel initiatives.

India Leads Global Market Expansion

India demonstrates the strongest growth potential in the used cooking oil market with a CAGR of 8.4% through 2035. The country's leadership position stems from rapid food service expansion, urbanization-driven restaurant proliferation, and increasing government focus on waste-to-energy initiatives enabling mainstream UCO collection adoption.

Growth is concentrated in major metropolitan regions, including Mumbai, Delhi, Bangalore, and Hyderabad, where concentrated restaurant districts and cloud kitchen clusters are generating substantial waste cooking oil volumes for commercial collection.

Infrastructure development through organized collection service providers, biodiesel startup ecosystems, and government-supported aggregation programs expands deployment across food service establishments, hotel chains, and institutional kitchens. The country's growing renewable energy sector provides policy support for biodiesel production, including ethanol blending program expansion and sustainable fuel incentives.

Key market factors:

UCO generation concentrated in metropolitan food service clusters with comprehensive collection service requirements

Infrastructure expansion through startup-led collection networks and municipal waste management partnerships

Comprehensive policy ecosystem, including biodiesel mandates with proven government support for renewable fuel adoption

Technology integration featuring digital collection platforms, quality tracking systems, and supply chain optimization technologies

China Emerges as High-Growth Market

In Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, the adoption of UCO collection is accelerating across commercial districts and food service zones, driven by environmental compliance requirements and circular economy policy support. The market demonstrates strong growth momentum with a CAGR of 8.1% through 2035, linked to high UCO generation from dense urban markets, growing collection infrastructure development, and comprehensive waste management modernization programs.

Chinese authorities are implementing mandatory UCO collection protocols and licensed collector networks to enhance proper disposal while meeting growing demand in expanding biodiesel production capacity and oleochemical manufacturing sectors. The country's circular economy initiatives create persistent demand for waste valorization systems, while increasing emphasis on food safety and waste oil tracking drives adoption of formalized collection and processing infrastructure.

Key development areas:

Urban food service sectors leading UCO generation with government-mandated collection participation

Licensed collection networks providing regulated supply chains with comprehensive traceability systems

Strategic partnerships between collection service providers and biodiesel producers are expanding market integration

Integration of digital tracking platforms and comprehensive quality verification systems

USA Shows Strong Regional Leadership

usa's market expansion is driven by diverse biodiesel production demand, including renewable diesel refineries and sustainable aviation fuel facilities across multiple states. The country demonstrates promising growth potential with a CAGR of 7.6% through 2035, supported by strong biodiesel processing infrastructure, renewable fuel standard compliance requirements, and established commercial collection networks.

American collectors face operational dynamics related to feedstock competition from animal fats, requiring efficient collection routing and support from large food service chains and quick-service restaurant partnerships. However, robust renewable fuel credit mechanisms and low carbon fuel standard programs create compelling economic drivers for UCO utilization, particularly in California and West Coast regions where carbon intensity reduction has direct impact on fuel credit values.

Market characteristics:

Biodiesel and renewable diesel industries showing strong feedstock demand with established procurement relationships

Regional concentration focused on California, Pacific Northwest, and Midwest biodiesel clusters

Future projections indicate continued policy support with renewable fuel standard extension programs

Growing emphasis on sustainable aviation fuel development driving premium pricing for verified UCO feedstock

Germany Demonstrates Technology Innovation

The German market leads in comprehensive waste oil management based on integration with advanced regulatory frameworks and certified collection systems for enhanced traceability. The country shows strong potential with a CAGR of 7.2% through 2035, driven by advanced waste oil regulation, comprehensive collection infrastructure, and expansion of biodiesel production facilities in major industrial centers, including North Rhine-Westphalia, Bavaria, and Baden-Württemberg.

German collection operators are implementing evidence-based UCO management practices for quality assurance and sustainability certification, particularly in regions with stringent environmental compliance requirements and specialized applications demanding comprehensive documentation standards. Technology deployment channels through certified waste management companies and licensed biodiesel producers expand coverage across food service operators and industrial collection points.

Leading market segments:

Food service and industrial sources implementing mandatory collection with comprehensive regulatory compliance

Collection partnerships with certification bodies, achieving sustainability scheme recognition and international market access

Strategic collaborations between German collectors and European biodiesel producers are expanding cross-border feedstock trade

Focus on quality assurance and traceability system requirements

usa Emphasizes Market Maturity

In major metropolitan markets including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Houston, food service operators are implementing comprehensive UCO collection programs to modernize waste management practices and monetize waste streams, with documented programs showing successful diversion of cooking oil from wastewater systems through commercial collection services. The market shows strong growth potential with a CAGR of 7.6% through 2035, linked to strong biodiesel processing capacity, renewable fuel standard incentives, and emerging low carbon fuel standard adoption in major states.

American food service chains are adopting systematic UCO collection protocols and sustainability reporting to enhance environmental credentials while maintaining operational efficiency demanded by corporate sustainability commitments and franchise standards. The country's established biodiesel industry creates persistent demand for feedstock diversification and supply reliability solutions that integrate with existing refining infrastructure.

Market development factors:

Food service chains and hospitality operators leading UCO collection participation across usa

Renewable fuel programs providing economic incentives through renewable identification number generation

Strategic partnerships between national collection companies and regional biodiesel producers are expanding supply networks

Emphasis on supply chain transparency and sustainability documentation across feedstock procurement

Japan Shows Consumer-Driven Growth

Japan's used cooking oil market demonstrates sophisticated waste management integration focused on municipal collection programs and community recycling participation, with documented adoption of household UCO recovery systems achieving high participation rates across residential waste management programs.

The country maintains steady growth momentum with a CAGR of 6.4% through 2035, driven by high recycling adoption rates, comprehensive environmental compliance culture, and municipal waste management excellence aligned with national sustainability goals.

Major urban regions, including Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Fukuoka, showcase advanced deployment of UCO collection where municipal programs integrate seamlessly with existing waste management systems and comprehensive resource recovery protocols.

Key market characteristics:

Municipal and community collection programs driving residential UCO recovery with emphasis on citizen participation and environmental education

Quality management partnerships enabling consistent feedstock specifications with comprehensive testing programs

Technology collaboration between Japanese waste management companies and biodiesel producers is expanding market capabilities

Emphasis on closed-loop systems and local resource utilization methodologies

Brazil Emphasizes Innovation and Biofuel Leadership

Brazil's used cooking oil market demonstrates growing integration landscape, characterized by connection with existing biodiesel industry infrastructure and sugarcane ethanol program synergies across diverse regional markets. The country shows steady growth momentum with a CAGR of 6.1% through 2035, driven by expansion of biofuel policies and renewable fuel mandate increases supporting biodiesel sector growth.

Brazil's emphasis on renewable energy leadership and energy independence creates requirements for diverse feedstock portfolios that support comprehensive biodiesel production protocols and fuel quality requirements in commercial operations.

The market benefits from established relationships between waste management operators and biodiesel producers, creating integrated supply ecosystems that prioritize feedstock availability and processing efficiency. Commercial centers in major metropolitan regions showcase advancing UCO collection implementations where service providers achieve reliable supply through integrated logistics programs.

Key market characteristics:

Food service and hospitality sectors driving UCO collection expansion with emphasis on organized collection services

Biodiesel industry partnerships enabling integrated feedstock supply with comprehensive quality protocols

Technology collaboration between Brazilian collection companies and biofuel producers is expanding market capabilities

Emphasis on feedstock diversification and supply reliability improvement methodologies

Australia Emphasizes Innovation and Sustainability Leadership

Australia's used cooking oil market demonstrates mature environmental compliance landscape, characterized by sophisticated integration of waste oil recovery with existing renewable energy programs and sustainability initiatives across commercial sectors. The country shows steady growth momentum with a CAGR of 5.8% through 2035, driven by growing sustainability compliance requirements and renewable fuel development initiatives in major commercial centers including Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Perth.

Australia's emphasis on circular economy principles and waste diversion targets creates requirements for comprehensive UCO collection systems that support biodiesel production protocols and renewable energy requirements in commercial operations. The market benefits from strong partnerships between commercial collection service providers and biodiesel manufacturers, creating comprehensive recovery ecosystems that prioritize service quality and environmental compliance. Food service markets in major urban regions showcase advanced collection implementations where commercial programs achieve high participation rates through integrated service programs.

Key market characteristics:

Commercial food service and hospitality sectors driving UCO collection requirements with emphasis on environmental compliance and waste diversion

Collection service partnerships enabling reliable feedstock supply with comprehensive quality management programs

Technology collaboration between Australian collectors and renewable fuel producers is expanding market capabilities

Emphasis on sustainability verification and carbon accounting methodologies

Europe Market Split by Country

The used cooking oil market in Europe is projected to grow from USD 2.4 billion in 2025 to USD 4.7 billion by 2035, registering a CAGR of 6.9% over the forecast period. Germany is expected to maintain its leadership position with a 32.8% market share in 2025, supported by its advanced waste management infrastructure, comprehensive biodiesel production capacity, and strong regulatory framework across major commercial centers.

The UK follows with a 21.5% share in 2025, driven by comprehensive food service collection programs implementing organized UCO recovery and renewable transport fuel obligation compliance. France holds a 18.3% share through established biodiesel industry and waste oil collection networks. Italy commands a 13.6% share, while Spain accounts for 8.9% in 2025.

The rest of Europe region maintains a 4.9% collective share, attributed to increasing UCO collection adoption in Nordic countries and emerging Eastern European waste management systems implementing circular economy programs. By 2035, Germany is projected to hold 32.4% share, UK 21.8%, France 18.6%, Italy 13.9%, Spain 9.1%, and Rest of Europe 4.2%, reflecting sustained growth momentum across all major European waste management markets.

Competitive Landscape of the Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market

The used cooking oil market features approximately 15-25 meaningful players with moderate concentration, where the top three companies control roughly 30-40% of global market share through established collection networks and extensive food service relationships. Competition centers on collection coverage, service reliability, and feedstock quality rather than price competition alone.

Market leaders include Darling Ingredients Inc., Baker Commodities Inc., and Olleco, which maintain competitive advantages through comprehensive waste collection service portfolios, extensive route networks, and deep expertise in the rendering and biodiesel feedstock sectors, creating high reliability among food service customers.

These companies leverage established customer relationships and ongoing service excellence to defend market positions while expanding into adjacent grease trap services and biodiesel production applications. Darling Ingredients Inc. commands a 15.6% market share through strategic vertical integration and multi-feedstock processing excellence.

Challengers encompass Arrow Oils Ltd. and Waste Oil Recyclers, which compete through established regional collection portfolios and strong presence in key food service markets. Collection specialists, including GRAND NATURAL INC., GREASECYCLE, and Brocklesby, focus on specific geographic regions or service models, offering differentiated capabilities in restaurant partnerships, automated collection systems, and sustainability reporting services.

Regional players and emerging collection service providers create competitive pressure through local market knowledge and customer proximity advantages, particularly in high-growth markets including India and China, where developing collection infrastructure provides opportunities for new market entrants.

Market dynamics favor companies that combine efficient collection logistics with comprehensive customer service capabilities that address the complete value chain from waste oil generation through processing and end-market delivery. Strategic vertical integration between collection companies and biodiesel producers accelerates market development, while digitalization initiatives enable route optimization and real-time feedstock tracking across collection operations.

Global Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market - Stakeholder Contribution Framework

Used cooking oil represents a critical renewable feedstock that enables biodiesel producers, oleochemical manufacturers, and renewable fuel refineries to achieve sustainability targets and regulatory compliance without virgin feedstock dependency, typically providing 80-85% greenhouse gas reduction compared to fossil diesel while enabling waste stream monetization.

With the market projected to grow from USD 8.56 billion in 2025 to USD 17.18 billion by 2035 at a 7.2% CAGR, this feedstock offers compelling advantages - proven carbon intensity benefits, established conversion technologies, and circular economy alignment - making it essential for biodiesel production (major application), sustainable aviation fuel development (emerging segment), and diverse renewable energy applications seeking waste-based feedstock solutions. Scaling collection infrastructure and supply reliability requires coordinated action across waste management policy, sustainability standards, collection service providers, biodiesel producers, and food service operators.

How Governments Could Spur Local Collection and Utilization?

Collection Infrastructure Programs: Include UCO recovery systems in municipal waste management initiatives, providing targeted funding for commercial collection equipment in urban centers and supporting collection service providers through route development grants and infrastructure assistance.

Regulatory Framework & Incentives: Implement mandatory UCO collection requirements for commercial food service, provide tax incentives for collection service investments, and establish favorable renewable fuel credit frameworks that encourage domestic utilization over export alternatives.

Circular Economy Support: Create streamlined waste oil transfer permits across collection and processing facilities, establish clear feedstock classification standards for UCO materials, and develop cross-border trade facilitation protocols that enable efficient feedstock movement.

Food Service Education Programs: Fund awareness campaigns for restaurant operators, commercial kitchen managers, and hospitality professionals. Invest in training initiatives that bridge proper disposal practices with collection service engagement and sustainability reporting capabilities.

How Industry Bodies Could Support Market Development?

Quality Standards & Certification: Define standardized feedstock specifications for UCO across biodiesel and oleochemical applications, establish universal testing protocols for contaminant levels, and create certification programs for collection quality that processors can specify.

Best Practices & Guidelines: Lead industry initiatives that demonstrate proper UCO management advantages, emphasizing proven environmental benefits, revenue generation opportunities, and regulatory compliance advantages compared to drain disposal practices.

Supply Chain Integration Standards: Develop traceability protocols for feedstock documentation, comprehensive chain-of-custody requirements, and sustainability certification platforms, ensuring verification credibility across different collection environments and processing requirements.

How Collection Companies and Processors Could Strengthen the Ecosystem?

Collection Infrastructure Development: Develop efficient collection route systems with optimized scheduling, reliable service delivery, and customer-friendly container solutions that enhance participation economics while reducing operational costs.

Quality Management Systems: Provide comprehensive feedstock testing that integrates contamination analysis, moisture content verification, free fatty acid measurement, and sustainability documentation, enabling processors to maximize conversion efficiency and regulatory credit generation.

Partnership Networks: Offer flexible service arrangements for food service operators and hospitality chains, including scheduled collection options, reporting services, and revenue-sharing programs that keep UCO recovery aligned with operational requirements and sustainability goals.

Baker Commodities Inc.

Olleco

title: Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics sign SAF agreement
description:
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have formalised their summer MoU on Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) into a long-term agreement, signed in Paris on November 21.
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have converted their Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on the use of SAF, announced in the summer, into a binding agreement.
The agreement was signed on November 21 at CEVA Logistics’ Airfreight Annual Strategic Partners Council in Paris.
For Lufthansa Cargo, the new agreement is another clear sign of the close and constructive cooperation with CEVA Logistics, which has proven particularly valuable in strategic future-oriented topics such as sustainability.
The emission reductions are transparently confirmed to CEVA Logistics via audited “Emission Mitigation Certificates” and are based on an audited “Proof of Sustainability” (PoS) at Lufthansa Cargo.
text:
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have formalised their summer MoU on Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) into a long-term agreement, signed in Paris on November 21.

Running through 2028, the deal will see CEVA credited with 8,000 tons of CO₂ reductions in 2025, using SAF sourced from waste materials and backed by audited sustainability certificates.

The agreement underscores both companies’ commitment to transparent, verifiable decarbonisation and expands their wider sustainability partnership, which also includes joint innovation, circular economy solutions, and knowledge-sharing.

Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have converted their Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on the use of SAF, announced in the summer, into a binding agreement. The agreement was signed on November 21 at CEVA Logistics’ Airfreight Annual Strategic Partners Council in Paris. The company has committed to using SAF, credited in 2025, which corresponds to a reduction of 8,000 tons of CO₂.

The decision to formalise the MoU in a long-term framework agreement running until the end of 2028 is an expression of a trusting cooperation that has grown over many years and is based on openness, continuous exchange, and mutual learning. “The agreement is a significant step in our sustainable partnership with Lufthansa Cargo and enables us to measurably reduce our CO₂ emissions and make our supply chains more sustainable. It is particularly important to us to do this with a partner who is committed to maximum transparency, clear sustainability standards, and reliable certifications,” says Loïc Gay, Global Air & Ocean Products VP at CEVA Logistics.

For Lufthansa Cargo, the new agreement is another clear sign of the close and constructive cooperation with CEVA Logistics, which has proven particularly valuable in strategic future-oriented topics such as sustainability. Both companies are committed to open exchange and to promoting solutions that have a real impact. “CEVA Logistics’ decision to make extensive use of SAF demonstrates its clear commitment to making an effective contribution to the decarbonisation of air freight. Climate protection requires strong partnerships and decisive action. This agreement creates a solid foundation for achieving further progress together,” says Anand Kulkarni, our Head of Global Markets.

In addition, the framework agreement structures further cooperation in the area of SAF and enables further measures to be taken in the future. The SAF used comes exclusively from waste and residual materials, is palm oil-free, and meets the highest international standards. The emission reductions are transparently confirmed to CEVA Logistics via audited “Emission Mitigation Certificates” and are based on an audited “Proof of Sustainability” (PoS) at Lufthansa Cargo. With the agreement now concluded, together we are sending a clear signal for verifiable CO₂ reduction and strengthening our long-term cooperation in the field of sustainable logistics solutions.

The SAF agreement is the latest part of a broader sustainability partnership between us, including knowledge sharing, circular economy solutions and joint innovation and research initiatives.

title: How EU RED is driving real sustainability in aviation and shifting the industry from claims to action.
description:
Imagine stepping into a plane that runs on recycled emissions, renewable electricity and water.
Starting in 2030, the ReFuelEU Aviation regulation requires that a share of all jet fuel used at EU airports must be synthetic, electricity-based sustainable aviation fuel called eSAF.
To ensure this fuel truly cuts emissions, the EU RED sets clear rules for how eSAF must be produced.
Producers must be able to show, with meters and records, that the amount of sustainable input matches the amount of sustainable fuel produced.
EU RED sets a high bar, and meeting it can be challenging, especially for emerging companies.
text:
Imagine stepping into a plane that runs on recycled emissions, renewable electricity and water. That’s not a distant dream, but a direction aviation is moving in. Starting in 2030, the ReFuelEU Aviation regulation requires that a share of all jet fuel used at EU airports must be synthetic, electricity-based sustainable aviation fuel called eSAF.

To ensure this fuel truly cuts emissions, the EU RED sets clear rules for how eSAF must be produced. These include strict control of supply chains, transparent tracking of sustainable materials, verified life-cycle emissions calculations, and a requirement that eSAF cuts emissions by at least 70 per cent compared to fossil-based jet fuel. In practice, this means eSAF producers must be certified before they can sell fuel in the EU.

Certified from source to sky

EU RED certification rests on three key requirements: sourcing sustainable inputs from approved suppliers, tracking material flows accurately through mass-balance, and verifying emissions across the full lifecycle.

Supply chain requirements

Every sustainable input used to produce eSAF, like captured biogenic CO₂ and green hydrogen, must come from EU RED-certified suppliers. Electricity providers don’t need certification themselves, but the electricity used must be genuinely renewable and, in many cases, meet strict criteria like being newly built, produced at the same time the fuel is made, and generated in the same region. These checks prevent eSAF production from competing with other sectors for renewable power.

Mass-balance tracking

In simple terms, the mass balance approach means that what goes in and what comes out during the production process is strictly accounted for. Producers must be able to show, with meters and records, that the amount of sustainable input matches the amount of sustainable fuel produced. This avoids situations where more “green” fuel is claimed than what is actually created.

Life-cycle emissions

To ensure real climate benefit, emissions are calculated across the whole journey from raw materials to fuel production, transport and final use. EU RED requires that eSAF cuts emissions by at least 70 per cent compared to fossil jet fuel, based on a standard EU formula.

Liquid Sun's path to certification

We have taken our first major step by becoming a member of the International Sustainability and Carbon Certification (ISCC) Association, one of the EU-approved schemes for demonstrating compliance with the EU RED. ISCC is widely trusted in the aviation and renewable energy sectors, making it a strong fit for our mission.

EU RED sets a high bar, and meeting it can be challenging, especially for emerging companies. But by joining ISCC early, we can build compliance into our processes from day one rather than retrofitting later. It gives us time to understand requirements, create the right systems and prepare for rigorous audits.

title: Work starts on new Malaysian biorefinery joint venture by PETRONAS, Enilive and Euglena
description:
The biorefinery would have the capacity to produce about 650,000 tonnes/year of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) and bio-naphtha from used vegetable oils, animal fats and vegetable processing waste upon completion, the companies said on 10 November.
The new facility in Pengerang, Johor, was scheduled to commence operations by the second half of 2028.
PETRONAS executive vice president and downstream CEO Sazali Hamzah said: “The groundbreaking of the Pengerang Biorefinery reflects the collective efforts to drive decarbonisation and advance energy transition in the region.” Located within the Pengerang Integrated Complex (PIC) in Johor, the biorefinery’s geographical position and access to major international shipping lanes would help it meet biofuel demand, particularly across the Asian region, the companies said.
When announcing the new biorefinery last July, the companies said PETRONAS Mobility Lestari Sdn Bhd (PMLSB), a subsidiary of PETRONAS alongside Enilive, would be the largest shareholders of the joint venture.
text:
The biorefinery would have the capacity to produce about 650,000 tonnes/year of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) and bio-naphtha from used vegetable oils, animal fats and vegetable processing waste upon completion, the companies said on 10 November.

The new facility in Pengerang, Johor, was scheduled to commence operations by the second half of 2028.

PETRONAS executive vice president and downstream CEO Sazali Hamzah said: “The groundbreaking of the Pengerang Biorefinery reflects the collective efforts to drive decarbonisation and advance energy transition in the region.”

Located within the Pengerang Integrated Complex (PIC) in Johor, the biorefinery’s geographical position and access to major international shipping lanes would help it meet biofuel demand, particularly across the Asian region, the companies said.

When announcing the new biorefinery last July, the companies said PETRONAS Mobility Lestari Sdn Bhd (PMLSB), a subsidiary of PETRONAS alongside Enilive, would be the largest shareholders of the joint venture.

title: Virgin Atlantic CEO Salary in 2025 - Aviation A2Z
authors: Atharva Khadilkar, Karan Bhatta, Helen William
description:
Virgin Atlantic (VS), one of the UK’s most iconic airlines, has always stood out for its flair, service, and daring marketing.
Virgin Atlantic CEO Shai Weiss’ Salary in 2025 As of the most recent disclosures, Shai Weiss’s base salary remains around £700,000 per year, consistent with his reported compensation since 2022.
Virgin Atlantic’s Plans for 2025 Looking ahead, Virgin Atlantic’s 2025 plans centre around sustainable expansion and financial strengthening.
As Virgin Atlantic eyes a stronger 2025, Weiss’s role remains pivotal.
Virgin Atlantic CEO Salary FAQs Stay tuned with us.
text:
Virgin Atlantic (VS), one of the UK’s most iconic airlines, has always stood out for its flair, service, and daring marketing. Founded by Sir Richard Branson in 1984, it remains a symbol of British entrepreneurial spirit.

The airline’s story over the last few years, however, has been one of steady resilience rather than glamour. Having battled through the pandemic and rising fuel costs, Virgin Atlantic has managed to claw its way back to profitability under the leadership of Shai Weiss, who has been at the helm since 2019.

In 2024, the carrier recorded its first profit since 2019, reporting a £20 million pre-tax profit and revenues of £3.3 billion. The performance came on the back of strong demand on transatlantic routes, where Virgin Atlantic operates alongside its joint venture partners Delta Air Lines, Air France, and KLM.

Advertisement

Its operational fleet of around 42 aircraft, largely made up of Airbus A330s, A350s, and Boeing 787 Dreamliners, forms the core of a long-haul network connecting London to destinations across North America, the Caribbean, Africa, and Asia.

As the airline continues to stabilise, much attention has turned to the man guiding its comeback and, naturally, to how he’s compensated for the task.

Who is Shai Weiss?

Shai Weiss, originally from Israel, has been with Virgin Atlantic since 2014, starting as Chief Financial Officer (CFO) before being promoted to Chief Executive Officer (CEO) in 2019.

He previously held senior roles at Virgin Media and several investment firms, building his background across finance and management. Educated in both Israel and the United States, he holds an MBA from Columbia Business School.

Within Virgin Atlantic, Weiss is known for his pragmatic leadership and calm temperament, traits that proved vital during the pandemic years when the airline’s survival was in question.

His decision-making was instrumental in securing refinancing deals and driving the restructuring plan that saved thousands of jobs. Weiss is also known for his balanced approach — a mix of financial discipline and the brand’s characteristic optimism.

Virgin Atlantic CEO Shai Weiss’ Salary in 2025

As of the most recent disclosures, Shai Weiss’s base salary remains around £700,000 per year, consistent with his reported compensation since 2022. His performance-based bonus potential can reach up to £1.05 million, depending on how the airline performs financially and operationally.

Virgin Atlantic has not yet released a detailed remuneration report for the 2025 financial year. However, considering the airline’s return to profitability in 2024 and its positive earnings outlook, it’s expected that Weiss’s bonus component will have been partly or fully activated.

Based on comparable pay structures from previous years, his total estimated remuneration for 2025 likely falls between £1.2 million and £1.4 million, assuming moderate incentive payouts.

His package includes standard executive benefits such as health insurance, company car allowance, travel privileges, and participation in Virgin Group’s long-term incentive plan. Unlike some of his peers in low-cost or larger network airlines, Weiss’s compensation structure is heavily tied to long-term profitability rather than short-term stock bonuses.

ALSO READ: Air France-KLM Group CEO Benjamin Smith Salary and Compensation

Peer Comparisons: British Airways and easyJet

To understand Weiss’s compensation in context, it’s worth looking at two of his UK-based counterparts: Sean Doyle, CEO of British Airways, and Kenton Jarvis, CEO of easyJet.

Sean Doyle (British Airways) reportedly earned around £1.4 million in total remuneration in 2024, including a base salary of about £670,000 and bonus incentives.

BA’s size, being part of the International Airlines Group (IAG), naturally justifies a larger total pay envelope. The group’s profitability and global scale are also far higher than Virgin Atlantic’s.

Kenton Jarvis (easyJet), who assumed the CEO position in January 2025, earns a base salary of £800,000, with performance bonuses and share-based incentives tied to the airline’s financial results. His package is slightly higher on the fixed pay side but carries similar proportions in bonus opportunities.

Compared with these, Shai Weiss’s total compensation is competitive but restrained. Virgin Atlantic is smaller than both British Airways and easyJet in fleet and network scale, so the relative positioning of Weiss’s salary makes sense. What stands out is that his pay is deeply performance-weighted — an approach reflecting the airline’s cautious recovery and investor expectations.

Governance and Pay Structure

Virgin Atlantic’s remuneration philosophy has always leaned towards balance. As a privately held company (jointly owned by the Virgin Group with 51%, Delta Air Lines with 49%, and Air France-KLM with a small stake), its executive compensation is not subject to the same level of public scrutiny as listed airlines. Still, the board maintains a framework that rewards leadership stability and long-term financial health rather than large annual bonuses.

Following the challenges of 2020–2022, Weiss voluntarily waived parts of his pay and bonus when the airline was undergoing restructuring. That gesture earned him goodwill both internally and externally, reinforcing his image as a steady and grounded leader.

Since then, the company has re-aligned its bonus metrics towards profitability, cash flow, and operational reliability — three areas Weiss has openly prioritised. His pay for 2025, while not officially disclosed in full, is expected to reflect these performance goals more than headline figures.

Virgin Atlantic’s Plans for 2025

Looking ahead, Virgin Atlantic’s 2025 plans centre around sustainable expansion and financial strengthening. The airline is ramping up capacity on transatlantic routes, especially to the United States, where demand has remained robust.

It has also resumed services to key leisure destinations such as Dubai, Miami, and the Caribbean islands, while considering further frequency increases to India and South Africa.

Fleet modernisation continues, with the Airbus A330neo now joining the lineup, promising improved fuel efficiency and passenger comfort. Sustainability sits at the heart of the company’s plans — Virgin Atlantic completed the world’s first 100% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) transatlantic flight in 2023 and is pushing forward with similar initiatives.

Operationally, the goal for 2025 is to achieve a stronger profit margin, improve punctuality, and manage rising fuel and maintenance costs. For Weiss, these objectives will directly influence any variable pay outcomes at the end of the fiscal year.

Bottom Line

Shai Weiss’s leadership has quietly stabilised Virgin Atlantic after a period of crisis and uncertainty. His pay structure reflects that measured, responsible approach — steady fixed compensation, and bonuses linked directly to the airline’s success. While not excessive by industry standards, it’s a fair reflection of the airline’s size, recovery stage, and ownership structure.

As Virgin Atlantic eyes a stronger 2025, Weiss’s role remains pivotal. His pay may not make headlines, but it symbolises a balance between ambition and realism — a fitting representation of how the airline itself has rebuilt from turbulence to renewed optimism.

Virgin Atlantic CEO Salary FAQs

Stay tuned with us. Further, follow us on social media for the latest updates.

title: UK Imposes Tariffs on Chinese Biodiesel to Combat Unfair Dumping - ChemAnalyst
description:
The Secretary of State for Business & Trade, on November 24, 2025, accepted the Trade Remedies Authority's (TRA) final recommendation to apply new definitive anti-dumping duties on biodiesel imports originating from China.
The final recommendation by the TRA confirmed that applying an anti-dumping measure is decisively in the UK's economic interest.
By raising the cost floor for these particular Chinese imports, the UK government is signaling a commitment to protecting domestic manufacturing capacity and fostering a stable investment environment for companies dedicated to the renewable fuel market.
The move is expected to maintain a level playing field, encouraging sustainable growth and investment within the UK's green economy.
The duties are set to apply for a period of five years, ensuring long-term protection for the domestic industry.
text:
The Secretary of State for Business & Trade, on November 24, 2025, accepted the Trade Remedies Authority's (TRA) final recommendation to apply new definitive anti-dumping duties on biodiesel imports originating from China. This decision, which came into effect on Tuesday, November 25, 2025, marks the conclusion of an extensive investigation launched in June 2024 following an application by the Renewable Transport Fuels Association (RTFA).

The TRA's investigation determined that Chinese biodiesel was being "dumped" in the UK market—a practice that was found to be causing "material injury" to UK-based producers, including major industry players such as Argent Energy and Olleco.

The new measures are structured as ad valorem duties, which are calculated as a percentage of the value of the imported goods. The rates vary based on the level of cooperation shown by the exporting companies during the investigation:

• 14.79% for the Zhuoyue Group and other non-sampled cooperating exporters.

• 54.64% for all other exporters from China.

The application of these duties is broad, covering key types of biodiesel: fatty-acid mono-alkylesters (FAME) and paraffinic gasoils obtained from synthesis or hydrotreatment of non-fossil origin (HVO), whether imported in pure form or as part of a blend. This move aims to secure fair competition across the renewable road transport fuel sector.

Crucially, in a nod to future sustainability goals, the duties explicitly exclude sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), in pure form or in a blend.

The final recommendation by the TRA confirmed that applying an anti-dumping measure is decisively in the UK's economic interest. The authority's findings were based on a thorough analysis of evidence and responses from interested parties following the publication of the Statement of Essential Facts.

By raising the cost floor for these particular Chinese imports, the UK government is signaling a commitment to protecting domestic manufacturing capacity and fostering a stable investment environment for companies dedicated to the renewable fuel market. The move is expected to maintain a level playing field, encouraging sustainable growth and investment within the UK's green economy. The duties are set to apply for a period of five years, ensuring long-term protection for the domestic industry.

title: Bell 505 logs over 700 flight hours on SAF blend, marking major milestone in green aviation efforts
description:
Bell Textron Inc., a Textron Inc. company, announced at European Rotors 2025 that a dedicated Bell 505 helicopter has crossed 700 flight hours operating on blended sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
Less than a year later, the Bell 505 became the world’s first single-engine helicopter to fly using 100% SAF during a demonstration.
Since July 2022, Bell has logged more than 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 at the Bell Training Academy.
“We are particularly pleased with these SAF flights in partnership with Bell,” said Jean-François Sauer, EVP Programs at Safran Helicopter Engines.
The Arrius 2R, like all our engines, can currently run on up to 50% drop-in SAF.
text:
Bell Textron Inc., a Textron Inc. company, announced at European Rotors 2025 that a dedicated Bell 505 helicopter has crossed 700 flight hours operating on blended sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The achievement marks a significant step in the company’s ongoing efforts to expand SAF use across its operations, reports ASD News.

“Bell is proud to celebrate this next step in industry carbon reduction objectives,” said Robin Wendling, Managing Director for Europe at Bell. “Working with Safran Helicopter Engines has given us an edge in pursuing greener aviation practices.”

Bell began collaborating with Safran Helicopter Engines in March 2022 to study the technical performance and economic impact of SAF on the Bell 505, which is powered by the Arrius 2R engine. Less than a year later, the Bell 505 became the world’s first single-engine helicopter to fly using 100% SAF during a demonstration. Since July 2022, Bell has logged more than 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 at the Bell Training Academy. Engine and aircraft performance assessments, along with inspections, have delivered positive results.

“We are particularly pleased with these SAF flights in partnership with Bell,” said Jean-François Sauer, EVP Programs at Safran Helicopter Engines. “SAF plays a key role in making helicopter operations more sustainable. The Arrius 2R, like all our engines, can currently run on up to 50% drop-in SAF. Very soon, they will be capable of operating on 100% drop-in SAF, helping expand the use of this fuel across the sector.”

The Bell 505 combines the Safran Arrius 2R engine with dual-channel FADEC and the Garmin G1000H NXi all-glass avionics suite featuring a moving-map display. Its panoramic windows, open cabin layout and Synthetic Vision technology make it one of the most advanced aircraft in its class and suitable for a wide range of missions, including public safety, utility operations and military training.

title: Indonesia's Pertamina ramping up efforts to produce sustainable aviation fuel
description:
Cilacap: Indonesia’s state-owned energy company Pertamina is intensifying efforts to scale up production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) as part of the country’s broader plan to reduce carbon emissions from air travel, reports Channel News India.
To boost SAF production, Pertamina is working to increase the proportion of used cooking oil in its blends.
“This can also be achieved by increasing the capacity and productivity of the green refinery unit.” Indonesia has significant potential supply.
The country uses about 6 to 7 million tonnes of cooking oil each year, said Pertamina deputy president director Oki Muraza.
“In the beginning, we collected around 80 kg to 100 kg of used cooking oil a month.
text:
Cilacap: Indonesia’s state-owned energy company Pertamina is intensifying efforts to scale up production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) as part of the country’s broader plan to reduce carbon emissions from air travel, reports Channel News India.

Pertamina is expanding SAF output at its existing refineries and is studying the development of new green refineries. At present, SAF is produced at the company’s Cilacap refinery in Central Java, while green refinery capabilities are being developed or planned at facilities in South Sumatra, Riau, West Java and East Kalimantan.

The Indonesian government aims to raise the national SAF blend mandate for international flights to 5% by 2035. At the COP30 climate conference in Belem, Brazil, the country announced a target of producing more than 1 million kilolitres of SAF annually by 2030, with used cooking oil set to be a major feedstock.

At Cilacap, the green refinery under development can produce about 1.4 million litres of SAF a day — roughly half the volume of an Olympic-size swimming pool. Around 3% of the feedstock currently comes from used cooking oil.

The refinery converts used cooking oil into SAF using a series of chemical processes. The oil is mixed with kerosene, heated to about 70°C and then moved into a reactor where it is further heated to over 300°C and passed through layers of catalysts that accelerate chemical reactions. Hydrogen is also added to stabilise the mixture. The result is a cleaner fuel suitable for jet engines, which can cut aviation emissions by up to 80% compared with conventional jet fuel.

To boost SAF production, Pertamina is working to increase the proportion of used cooking oil in its blends. Engineers are also experimenting with improved catalysts to raise efficiency. The current catalyst was developed locally by Pertamina’s technology innovation team in collaboration with the Bandung Institute of Technology, as part of a national effort to reduce reliance on imported catalysts.

“Our research and development team is always trying to improve the catalyst so that the used cooking oil content can be increased to more than 3%,” said process engineer Novan Adhi Prakasa. “This can also be achieved by increasing the capacity and productivity of the green refinery unit.”

Indonesia has significant potential supply. The country uses about 6 to 7 million tonnes of cooking oil each year, said Pertamina deputy president director Oki Muraza. “If we could collect just 20% of that, like in developed countries, we would have a large amount of raw material — enough to supply the domestic industry.”

Communities are already contributing to the SAF supply chain. In the Tegalreja district near the Cilacap refinery, residents are selling their used cooking oil to local waste banks instead of discarding it. Each kilogram earns around US$0.30.

“Used cooking oil is something every household has. Selling it adds to our income. Even if it’s just a little, it helps,” said Bartinah, a resident of KB Gadis village. “It gives us motivation and hope that one day the price could rise even higher, maybe up to 10,000 rupiah (US$0.60) per kilogram.”

Indonesia has an estimated potential of around 1 million litres of used cooking oil annually, but nearly 95% of it is exported to Europe and other Asian markets. Local collection initiatives could redirect more of this toward domestic SAF production.

“In the beginning, we collected around 80 kg to 100 kg of used cooking oil a month. Now, it’s up to about 170 kg,” said Sri Widowati, coordinator of the Tegalreja Waste Bank.

This expanding community involvement, combined with Pertamina’s refinery upgrades, is expected to play a central role in Indonesia’s push to build a robust and scalable SAF ecosystem.

title: Inside LanzaJet's Groundbreaking Ethanol-to-SAF Plant | Manufacturing Digital
description:
US-based company LanzaJet has achieved a manufacturing milestone, commencing the production of commercial sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from ethanol.
This development could play a role in reducing the carbon footprint of the aviation industry.
LanzaJet’s achievement is also notable as it represents the first time a non-oil-based renewable fuel of this type has reached commercial production levels.
By focusing on ethanol, this technology could open up new avenues for waste and recycled carbon to be used in aviation fuel production.
The move towards ethanol-based fuel production could offer nations a way to enhance their domestic energy security while also supporting their agricultural sectors.
text:
US-based company LanzaJet has achieved a manufacturing milestone, commencing the production of commercial sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from ethanol.

The company's Freedom Pines Fuels plant in Soperton, Georgia, is now fully operational, marking the first time its alcohol-to-jet (ATJ) technology has been deployed at a commercial scale following 15 years of research and development.

The fuel produced at the Georgia facility is a ‘drop-in’ solution, meaning it is fully compatible with existing aircraft and airport infrastructure and can be used as a direct replacement for traditional jet fuels.

This development could play a role in reducing the carbon footprint of the aviation industry. LanzaJet’s achievement is also notable as it represents the first time a non-oil-based renewable fuel of this type has reached commercial production levels.

Alcohol-to-jet manufacturing

Industry analysts have noted that SAF production using Hydroprocessed Esters and Fatty Acids (HEFA) may be nearing a limit based on feedstock availability. LanzaJet's technology offers an alternative pathway.

LanzaJet's proprietary process utilises widely available ethanol feedstocks, including agricultural residues and municipal solid waste, to bypass potential supply chain bottlenecks.

By focusing on ethanol, this technology could open up new avenues for waste and recycled carbon to be used in aviation fuel production.

"LanzaJet had made history: producing jet fuel from ethanol at the world's first commercial-scale plant," says Flyn van Ewijk, Regional Director for APAC at LanzaJet.

"This moment is not only hugely important for the LanzaJet family – the culmination of 15 years of research and development, collaboration, investment, and scale-up – but also for our industry as it marks the next wave of SAF technology to reach commercial readiness in nearly a decade."

Scaling production with integrated technologies

LanzaJet refers to the Soperton plant as a "first-of-its-kind" integrated solution. The manufacturing process combines Technip Energies’ Hummingbird Ethanol-to-Ethylene technology with an oligomerisation process developed jointly by LanzaTech and the US Department of Energy.

The successful integration and troubleshooting of these technologies at the facility now serves as a blueprint for future deployments globally.

Jimmy Samartzis, CEO at LanzaJet, comments: "Today proves what happens when you bring together innovation, resilience, ingenuity and teamwork to think big and develop a new industry, overcome challenges and enable global growth.

“We’re now in a unique position with technology and operational know-how to shape this global industry in the decade ahead.”

Global implications for fuel manufacturing

LanzaJet is already working to deliver this manufacturing technology to several other regions, including the UK, the European Union, Japan, and Australia.

The move towards ethanol-based fuel production could offer nations a way to enhance their domestic energy security while also supporting their agricultural sectors.

The fuel produced through this process delivers substantially lower lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions when compared to conventional kerosene.

Flyn acknowledges the operational challenges faced during the project's development: "Deploying a first-of-its-kind is not easy, but we've done it.

"I'm proud of our team for what they have achieved and grateful for Jimmy Samartzis's leadership and to Louay Masarweh for his many sleepless nights and unwavering dedication to the mission."

The construction of the Freedom Pines Fuels facility involved an investment of more than US$300m.

The final product can be blended with standard Jet A-1 and requires no modifications to existing aircraft engines or airport infrastructure, paving the way for its adoption in the commercial aviation sector.

title: Why LanzaJet's SAF Plant is a Game-Changer for Aviation | Construction Digital
description:
After 15 years of research and development, US firm LanzaJet has reached a milestone, confirming the first production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from ethanol at its Freedom Pines Fuels plant in Soperton, Georgia.
The facility is the first in the world to commercially produce SAF from ethanol, representing a major step in the decarbonisation of aviation.
LanzaJet has moved its alcohol-to-jet (ATJ) technology from a laboratory setting to a commercial one for the first time.
A blueprint for construction and technology integration LanzaJet calls the Soperton plant a "first-of-its-kind" integrated solution.
This change to ethanol could open new pathways for waste sources and recycled carbon to enter the aviation energy supply chain.
text:
After 15 years of research and development, US firm LanzaJet has reached a milestone, confirming the first production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from ethanol at its Freedom Pines Fuels plant in Soperton, Georgia.

The facility is the first in the world to commercially produce SAF from ethanol, representing a major step in the decarbonisation of aviation.

LanzaJet has moved its alcohol-to-jet (ATJ) technology from a laboratory setting to a commercial one for the first time. The fuel produced is a 'drop-in' replacement for conventional jet fuel, meaning it is fully compatible with existing aircraft and airport infrastructure without requiring any modifications.

This achievement could go a long way towards shrinking the carbon footprint of the airline industry.

A blueprint for construction and technology integration

LanzaJet calls the Soperton plant a "first-of-its-kind" integrated solution.

The project, which involved an investment of more than US$300m, successfully integrated Technip Energies’ Hummingbird Ethanol-to-Ethylene solution with oligomerisation technology developed jointly by LanzaTech and the US Department of Energy.

The successful construction and integration of these systems now serve as a blueprint for future deployments globally.

Jimmy Samartzis, CEO at LanzaJet, comments: “Today proves what happens when you bring together innovation, resilience, ingenuity and teamwork to think big and develop a new industry, overcome challenges and enable global growth.

"We’re now in a unique position with technology and operational know-how to shape this global industry in the decade ahead.”

Engineering past feedstock challenges

The aviation industry has faced warnings from analysts that SAF produced using Hydroprocessed Esters and Fatty Acids (HEFA) is nearing a limit in terms of available feedstock.

LanzaJet’s proprietary ATJ technology bypasses this potential bottleneck by using widely available ethanol feedstocks such as agricultural residues and municipal solid waste.

This change to ethanol could open new pathways for waste sources and recycled carbon to enter the aviation energy supply chain.

Flyn van Ewijk, Regional Director for APAC at LanzaJet, adds: "Overnight, we shared news that LanzaJet had made history: producing jet fuel from ethanol at the world's first commercial-scale plant.

"This moment is a milestone for the LanzaJet family – the culmination of 15 years of research and development, collaboration, investment and scale-up – but also for our industry as it marks the next wave of SAF technology to reach commercial readiness in nearly a decade."

Global deployment and energy security

LanzaJet is already planning to deliver this technology to multiple regions, including the UK, European Union, Japan and Australia.

The move towards ethanol-based fuel production presents an opportunity for nations to strengthen domestic energy security while simultaneously expanding their agricultural sectors. The fuel itself delivers far fewer lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions than conventional kerosene.

Deploying a novel engineering project of this scale presents major operational difficulties.

"Deploying a first-of-its-kind is not easy, but we've done it," says Flyn.

"I'm proud of our team for what they have achieved and grateful for Jimmy Samartzis's leadership and to Louay Masarweh for his many sleepless nights and unwavering dedication to the mission."
