title: TRA recommendation to impose duties on Chinese biodiesel accepted - GOV.UK
description:
On the 24 November 2025, the Secretary of State accepted the Trade Remedies Authority’s final recommendation to apply a new anti-dumping duty on imports of biodiesel from China.
The TRA found that Chinese biodiesel has been dumped in the UK at unfairly low prices, causing material injury to UK producers, including Argent Energy and Olleco.
These duties will help ensure fair competition for UK producers while maintaining a level playing field in the renewable fuel market.
This investigation was launched on 5 June 2024, following an application from the Renewable Transport Fuels Association (RTFA), on behalf of UK producers.
Anti-dumping duties are applied when a foreign producer exports goods at prices below their normal value, causing harm to domestic industry.
text:
On the 24 November 2025, the Secretary of State accepted the Trade Remedies Authority’s final recommendation to apply a new anti-dumping duty on imports of biodiesel from China.

The TRA found that Chinese biodiesel has been dumped in the UK at unfairly low prices, causing material injury to UK producers, including Argent Energy and Olleco.

Following its analysis of the evidence and responses from interested parties to the Statement of Essential Facts, the TRA has confirmed that the application of an anti-dumping measure is in the UK’s economic interest and made a final recommendation to apply duties. These duties will help ensure fair competition for UK producers while maintaining a level playing field in the renewable fuel market.

The measures recommended by the TRA are ad valorem duties of:

14.79% for the Zhuoyue Group and non-sampled cooperating exporters

54.64% for all other exporters

These duties will apply to imports of biodiesel, including fatty-acid mono-alkylesters (FAME) or paraffinic gasoils obtained from synthesis or hydrotreatment of non-fossil origin (HVO) in pure form or as included in a blend, excluding sustainable aviation fuel, in pure form or as included in a blend.

The duties will come into effect from Tuesday 25 November 2025.

Notes to Editors:

The Trade Remedies Authority is the UK’s independent body which investigates whether trade remedy measures are needed to counter unfair import practices.

This investigation was launched on 5 June 2024, following an application from the Renewable Transport Fuels Association (RTFA), on behalf of UK producers.

The final determination follows the publication of a Statement of Essential Facts and a stakeholder consultation period.

Anti-dumping duties are applied when a foreign producer exports goods at prices below their normal value, causing harm to domestic industry.

The TRA considers a range of evidence, including economic impact, before making a recommendation to the Secretary of State.

title: Sustainable Jet Fuel Developers Tap Wase for Fuel - Waste360
description:
The sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) market is expected to reach nearly $66 billion by 2030 and soar to $655 billion by 2050, and jet fuel tech developers are latching on to waste as feedstock to meet demand.
He has since spent years trying to figure out how to make jet fuel at scale and cheaper than has been done to date.
Today’s pilot produces about a gallon of jet fuel a day.
Drop-in sustainable aviation fuel is one of the few scalable pathways to reduce emissions in an industry where electrification and alternative energy carriers are extraordinarily difficult,” Werner says.
This year in Georgia, LanzaJet became the first to commercially produce jet fuel from ethanol.
text:
The sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) market is expected to reach nearly $66 billion by 2030 and soar to $655 billion by 2050, and jet fuel tech developers are latching on to waste as feedstock to meet demand. The first innovators have focused largely on agricultural byproducts, but there isn’t enough of the material to satiate airlines’ appetites as they commit to net-zero carbon by 2050. So, some developers are beginning to look at biogas from landfills, wastewater treatment plants, and dairy manure.

The University of Sydney developed a plasma technology to convert landfill gas into SAF. Syzygy Plasmonics says its system can also make SAF from landfill and wastewater biogas, among waste stream byproducts. Now, startup Circularity Fuels is working to make a go in this nascent but growing niche. The Redwood, California, company is beginning with dairy manure.

It seemed like a good pathway due to California’s low carbon-fuel standards (LCFS) incentive program, says Stephen Beaton, a jet fuel scientist turned entrepreneur who launched Circularity Fuels in 2023.

“By converting that gas, we're displacing fossil fuel. But we are also preventing the venting of methane through the atmosphere. So, we get more subsidies and incentives for the fuel,” he says.

Beaton believes SAF can open a lot more opportunities for the renewable natural gas (RNG) industry at a time when existing markets, mainly fuel for bus and truck fleet operators, are becoming increasingly saturated. Some developers are having a harder time getting their products into the few states that dole out incentives for RNG as transportation fuel.

“We can take advantage of many of the same subsidies, credits, and corporate programs by producing fuel for aviation in a market that is almost infinitely scalable,” Beaton says.

Still, there is more biogas worldwide than all the fuel-hungry airlines combined require. So the feedstock exists. The key to scaling is more a matter of developing technology and equipment that are affordable to deploy, which takes time.

In an earlier day, Beaton worked on novel fuels for the Air Force, then at the Pentagon, standing up the Air Force's synthetic aviation program. He has since spent years trying to figure out how to make jet fuel at scale and cheaper than has been done to date. Something a little different about Circularity’s model is that the company owns both primary steps of the process that follow anaerobic digestion: making the fuel precursor, syngas, then converting that syngas into jet fuel.

Verticalizing the technology stack to be able to perform the whole process in-house is generating cost and energy efficiencies, as is the technology itself. The system, which uses a modified automotive catalytic converter, is more compact and cheaper to run than traditional methane reforming equipment. Not having to filter out the carbon dioxide (CO2) from the waste stream helps.

“We actually use the CO2 in the process, which allows us to make more syngas per unit of biogas. And by combining the methane and CO2, the syngas is naturally at the ratio required for liquid fuel production [bypassing additional steps],” Beaton says.

While Beaton focuses on finetuning the first on-farm demo, he is thinking ahead, talking with landfills, feedlots, and wastewater treatment plants as well as biogas and RNG developers who are looking for outlets for their gas. On the offtake side, the young company so far has nondisclosure agreements with about half a dozen airlines. Optimizing is a slow-going process as there are some fundamental but complex principles to prove out.

Today’s pilot produces about a gallon of jet fuel a day. The plan is to scale to 100 million gallons per year by the mid-2030s. That would fuel roughly 10,000 transatlantic flights – about 35 million miles of long-haul air travel, Beaton says. So far, he and his team have secured about $9.5 million in seed funding and grants from venture capital firms, the National Science Foundation, California Energy Commission, and others.

The primary funder, DCVC, brought the startup into its entrepreneur-in-residence program, which backs “deep tech” developers aiming to transform underused or low-grade resources into valued products at scale. Producing fuels from waste fits squarely with that focus, says Milo Werner, a partner at DCVC focused on climate.

“Aviation is a natural priority because it is one of the hardest sectors to decarbonize. Drop-in sustainable aviation fuel is one of the few scalable pathways to reduce emissions in an industry where electrification and alternative energy carriers are extraordinarily difficult,” Werner says.

What stood out about Beaton and his team is that they found a way to avoid costly pre-treatment steps and infrastructure barriers that limit traditional reforming technologies (there is no need for a connection to a pipeline).

“Their approach has potential to bring down the cost of SAF production by an order of magnitude. That combination of technical advantage, cost disruption, and applicability to a hard-to-abate sector made Circularity a compelling investment,” Werner says.

Countries around the world are providing incentives and/or implementing SAF mandates to take these emerging technologies further. And these policies are driving demand. Commercial airlines are leaning in to figure out how to secure SAF years in advance of production. Right now, what product is available to them comes with sticker shock. Compared to the roughly $2.50 per gallon cost of traditional jet diesel, airlines pay $7 or $8 per gallon for clean fuels. Renewables that do not come from crop waste, and therefore don’t compete with food production, cost more. Making it more affordable is a work in progress.

Other issues are tough competition for the more widely used feedstocks (ag byproducts) and the availability of energy as companies compete for this resource too. Then there is regulatory uncertainty, particularly in the U.S., where the landscape has shifted.

While the Inflation Reduction Act created a $1.75 a gallon credit for SAF, that figure recently dropped to $1 per gallon. Now several members of Congress have introduced bills aiming to bolster incentives. Airlines can still tap into RINS credits through the U.S. EPA. Though key programs once offered by the U.S. Department of Agriculture have stalled, with uncertainty over whether they will reopen.

But slowly, a few domestic SAF projects are coming online and scaling up, with a handful more slated to launch soon. This year in Georgia, LanzaJet became the first to commercially produce jet fuel from ethanol. In Texas, Diamond Green Diesel is making SAF from used cooking oil and animal byproducts; with an annual capacity of 70 million tons, the corporation is reportedly the world’s largest producer of waste-based jet fuel.

But airlines will need 500 million tons of SAF a year to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, according to the International Air Transport Association. As far as Beaton’s contribution, admittedly, he says, if he meets his aspired targets, he alone will only make a dent. Though he is an optimist. He sees potential for healthy growth ahead in a budding industry.

“California scaled quickly from a very small percentage of compressed natural gas to essentially having 100% of vehicles run on biogas today. We think that scale can exist [for SAF].”

title: Emirates and ENOC Group sign MoU to explore Sustainable Aviation Fuel supply in Dubai
description:
Emirates and ENOC Group announced the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to explore and develop joint initiatives for the supply of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) to Emirates at its Dubai hub.
The MoU creates a framework for feasibility studies to assess SAF supply opportunities in Dubai, including supply chain infrastructure, production capabilities, and commercial viability.
The collaboration aims to explore pathways for developing economically feasible SAF production and supply infrastructure in Dubai, with ENOC evaluating its potential contribution to local production.
* Emirates is actively engaged in advancing the UAE's sustainable aviation fuel ecosystem through membership in the Technical Group under the Aviation Fuels Executive Committee, convened by the Ministry of Energy and Infrastructure, and the Dubai Biofuels, Hydrogen and Sustainable Aviation Fuel Committee, established by the Dubai Supreme Council of Energy.
That same month, Emirates operated flights with sustainable aviation fuel from Dubai International Airport using 315,000 gallons of blended SAF integrated into the airport’s fuel infrastructure.
text:
Emirates and ENOC Group announced the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to explore and develop joint initiatives for the supply of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) to Emirates at its Dubai hub.

The MoU creates a framework for feasibility studies to assess SAF supply opportunities in Dubai, including supply chain infrastructure, production capabilities, and commercial viability. The collaboration aims to explore pathways for developing economically feasible SAF production and supply infrastructure in Dubai, with ENOC evaluating its potential contribution to local production. A joint steering committee will guide the evaluation.

As a safe and fully certified drop-in fuel compatible with existing aircraft fleet and airport infrastructure, SAF can be blended with conventional jet fuel at a ratio of up to 50%, creating an aviation fuel that is significantly lower in lifecycle carbon emissions. In its neat form, SAF can reduce lifecycle emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional jet fuel.*

Emirates is actively engaged in advancing the UAE's sustainable aviation fuel ecosystem through membership in the Technical Group under the Aviation Fuels Executive Committee, convened by the Ministry of Energy and Infrastructure, and the Dubai Biofuels, Hydrogen and Sustainable Aviation Fuel Committee, established by the Dubai Supreme Council of Energy.

The airline has contributed to the UAE's General Policy for Sustainable Aviation Fuel, which aims to transform the UAE into a regional hub for alternative aviation fuels with production targets of 700 million litres by 2030. Additionally, Emirates and the UAE GCAA have played key roles in developing the UAE's power-to-liquid (PtL) fuels roadmap, driven by the Ministry of Energy and Infrastructure and the World Economic Forum.

Emirates also spearheaded SAF demonstration flights on its Boeing 777 and A380 aircraft. In January 2023, the airline operated a Boeing 777 flight using 100% SAF in one engine, and in November 2023 conducted the first A380 demonstration flight using 100% sustainable aviation fuel in one of its four engines. That same month, Emirates operated flights with sustainable aviation fuel from Dubai International Airport using 315,000 gallons of blended SAF integrated into the airport’s fuel infrastructure.

During its 2024-25 financial year, the airline procured 7,519 tonnes of SAF at airports across its network, including Amsterdam, London Heathrow, Oslo, Singapore, Paris, Lyon and Nice.

[*] Calculated with established life cycle assessment (LCA) methodologies, such as CORSIA methodology

Source: Emirates

title: BSR laboratory achieves ISO/IEC 17025:2017 certification – A foundation for quality control ...
description:
According to the accreditation decision, the BSR Laboratory is authorized to conduct 67 test methods in the refining and petrochemical field, covering gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, LPG, crude oil, and more.
First, the certification ensures quality control for biofuels and SAF - products requiring strict assessment of chemical composition, oxidative stability, impurities, and safety indicators.
The BSR Laboratory is accredited to ISO/IEC 17025:2017, valid through 2030 Mr. Pham Cong Nguyen, Manager of the Safety and Quality Division, emphasized: “ISO/IEC 17025:2017 provides the foundation for BSR to control the quality of biofuels and sustainable fuels, supporting the Government’s strategy for sustainable development and international integration.
The BSR Laboratory also participates in national and international proficiency testing programs to benchmark performance and enhance result reliability.
These efforts not only ensure sustained compliance with ISO/IEC 17025 but also enhance technical capacity to meet quality control requirements for new products such as E10, B5, B10, and SAF.
text:
Notably, BSR’s Laboratory first received the VILAS 456 accreditation in 2010 and has continuously maintained and expanded its scope of accreditation through regular evaluations.

According to the accreditation decision, the BSR Laboratory is authorized to conduct 67 test methods in the refining and petrochemical field, covering gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, LPG, crude oil, and more. The scope has been expanded to include new products such as PP resin, biofuels (E10, B5, B10), and Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) - a strategic product line of BSR amid the global trend of emissions reduction.

As the Government advances the roadmap for using E10 bio-gasoline and B5/B10 biodiesel to reduce emissions and protect the environment, and simultaneously promotes research and application of SAF, BSR’s attainment of ISO/IEC 17025:2017 carries special significance.

First, the certification ensures quality control for biofuels and SAF - products requiring strict assessment of chemical composition, oxidative stability, impurities, and safety indicators. With its broad accreditation scope, BSR can fully evaluate these parameters directly at the Dung Quat Refinery.

Furthermore, internationally accredited testing capability enables BSR to meet regulatory requirements while strengthening market confidence during the country’s transition toward green energy and sustainable aviation fuel development.

The BSR Laboratory is accredited to ISO/IEC 17025:2017, valid through 2030

Mr. Pham Cong Nguyen, Manager of the Safety and Quality Division, emphasized: “ISO/IEC 17025:2017 provides the foundation for BSR to control the quality of biofuels and sustainable fuels, supporting the Government’s strategy for sustainable development and international integration. Achieving this certification helps BSR save costs and time by eliminating the need for external testing; proactively control product quality; meet both regulatory and customer requirements; and enhance credibility and global integration, thereby facilitating exports and expanding technical cooperation.”

To ensure the laboratory management system operates effectively and continuously improves, BSR’s Safety and Quality Division has implemented key initiatives such as training and competency assessment for engineers and analysts. Each year, hundreds of internal training sessions and competency assessments are conducted. In 2025 alone, 1,125 competency assessments and over 100 on-the-job training sessions covering 89 analytical parameters were completed, ensuring personnel mastery of equipment and analytical methods.

Additionally, the Laboratory has actively performed thousands of periodic equipment checks to maintain accuracy and stability. In 2025, a total of 8,099 equipment inspections, calibrations, and maintenance activities were recorded, ensuring full readiness for analysis.

The BSR Laboratory also participates in national and international proficiency testing programs to benchmark performance and enhance result reliability. In 2025, the Division joined 11 proficiency testing rounds involving hundreds of parameters, achieving an excellent Z-score rate (≤ 2). It also organized three inter-laboratory comparison rounds with participation from over 20 laboratories across the country, contributing to method standardization and strengthened analytical capability.

These efforts not only ensure sustained compliance with ISO/IEC 17025 but also enhance technical capacity to meet quality control requirements for new products such as E10, B5, B10, and SAF.

This recognition celebrates the Foundation’s dedication and success in generating positive outcomes through its pioneering sustainable procurement tools and standards.
Kelsey Frenkiel, Director of Sustainability at the GBTA Foundation SPLC is delighted to acknowledge GBTA Foundation’s superb leadership in the field of sustainable procurement.
Marc Heisterkamp, SPLC CEO The SPLC Leadership Awards ceremony will be held virtually on Wednesday, December 3, at 2:00 pm EST.
About GBTA The Global Business Travel Association (GBTA) is the world's premiere business travel and meetings trade organization headquartered in the Washington, D.C. area and serving stakeholders across six continents.
About the GBTA Foundation The mission of the GBTA Foundation, the US 501c3 charitable arm of the Global Business Travel Association, is to help the global business travel industry create a positive impact and better future for people and the planet.
text:
The Sustainable Purchasing Leadership Council (SPLC) has named the GBTA Foundation, the cause-related arm of GBTA, a distinguished recipient of its 2025 Leadership Award in the Public Interest Advocate category. This recognition celebrates the Foundation’s dedication and success in generating positive outcomes through its pioneering sustainable procurement tools and standards.

The GBTA Foundation’s work to embed sustainability into an industry with $1.57 trillion in purchasing power culminated in 2024 with the release of the GBTA Sustainable Procurement Standards, which enable corporate travel buyers to consistently assess suppliers’ sustainability efforts. Developed in collaboration with GBTA Sustainability Partners and Sustainability Committee, the standards were vetted by more than 50 companies (buying organizations and travel suppliers like airlines, hotels, and car rental companies), as well as standard setters such as the International Air Transport Association, Travalyst and the World Sustainable Hospitality Alliance.

In the latest GBTA Sustainability Acceleration Challenge global benchmark, announced on November 10, 38% of companies say they consider climate criteria in supplier selection, and in 2026, the GBTA Foundation will be releasing a suite of practical tools to aid in their analysis. This will include case studies and scorecard templates which will allow buyers to make sustainable and data-driven decisions in procurement.

We’re proud to be recognized by SPLC, a respected leader in sustainable procurement. This recognition reinforces our conviction that strong collaboration across the travel supply chain can lead to meaningful transformation. Sustainable procurement is no longer optional—it’s becoming the foundation for how responsible businesses operate, and we’re excited to help drive that shift. Kelsey Frenkiel, Director of Sustainability at the GBTA Foundation

SPLC is delighted to acknowledge GBTA Foundation’s superb leadership in the field of sustainable procurement. The GBTA Foundation’s creative methodology and demonstrated, measurable impact underscore the vital, transformative role sustainable procurement plays. Their success offers a compelling example for organizations globally aiming to create a better future. Marc Heisterkamp, SPLC CEO

The SPLC Leadership Awards ceremony will be held virtually on Wednesday, December 3, at 2:00 pm EST. Registration details can be found on the SPLC Calendar of Events.

About GBTA

The Global Business Travel Association (GBTA) is the world's premiere business travel and meetings trade organization headquartered in the Washington, D.C. area and serving stakeholders across six continents. GBTA and its 8,000+ members represent and advocate for the $1.48 trillion global travel business and meetings industry. GBTA and the GBTA Foundation deliver world-class education, events, research, advocacy and media to a growing global network of more than 28,000 travel professionals and 125,000 active contacts. For more information visit gbta.org.

About the GBTA Foundation

The mission of the GBTA Foundation, the US 501c3 charitable arm of the Global Business Travel Association, is to help the global business travel industry create a positive impact and better future for people and the planet. The GBTA Foundation focuses on the strategy and execution of GBTA's global sustainability programs, supporting initiatives related to climate action; diversity, equity and inclusion; and other talent-related topics via education, research and advocacy. For more information visit gbtafoundation.org.

title: NetJets has pre-sold 'well over half' of expected 2026 deliveries
description:
NetJets has pre-sold over half of the private jets it expects to receive in 2026.
The world’s largest private jet operator has option agreements with Bombardier, Embraer, and Textron Aviation.
It has been 28 weeks since the worldwide private jet industry has seen negative year-over-year growth.
NetJets Growth NetJets operates over 1,400 flights daily, according to its website.
In September 2023, NetJets signed an options agreement with Textron for up to 1,500 jets, valued at around $30 billion.
text:
NetJets has pre-sold over half of the private jets it expects to receive in 2026.

The world’s largest private jet operator has option agreements with Bombardier, Embraer, and Textron Aviation.

Sales Achievement

News of the sales achievement came from NetJets Aviation President Patrick Gallagher.

Posting on social media, he wrote, “With the end of the year in sight, I’d like to applaud the accomplishments of the NetJets sales team.”

Gallagher continued, “In addition to a successful 2025, the team has already pre-sold well over half of the aircraft that we expect to take delivery of next year!”

He concluded, “Thank you for all you do—especially while staying focused on maintaining strong relationships with our owners this holiday season and into the new year.”

At the beginning of November, NetJets had 818 aircraft in its fleet.

That doesn’t include aircraft managed by its Executive Jet Management unit.

NetJets Fleet as of November 2025

The 2026 outlook comes as WingX and ARGUS TRAQPak data show the industry is on track to break its 2021 record, then broken in 2022, after two years of slight declines.

Per WingX, on a week-over-week basis, the industry has seen 40 of 46 weeks with gains, three weeks equal to last year, and only three down weeks.

It has been 28 weeks since the worldwide private jet industry has seen negative year-over-year growth.

NetJets Growth

NetJets operates over 1,400 flights daily, according to its website.

Officials have previously pegged annual deliveries at 80-100.

In September 2023, NetJets signed an options agreement with Textron for up to 1,500 jets, valued at around $30 billion.

That followed a similar deal with Embraer in May 2023 for up to 250 Praetor 500s.

Last year was a deal with Bombardier.

According to parent company Berkshire Hathaway’s annual report, it ended 2024 with over 9,000 employees.

The headcount at NetJets increased to 9,106 from 8,349 in 2023.

That also compares to 6,476 employees at NetJets back in 2019.

title: UK Central Government - Addleshaw Goddard LLP
description:
We understand both the legal framework within which the public sector operates, and the high level of political scrutiny which is applied to the decisions public sector bodies make.
We know that contract terms and our advice must consider the wider strategic, policy and economic objectives under which our public sector clients operate.
Our agile Central Government and Public Sector teams work from offices across the UK, combining true national reach with local roots.
Our Local Government team are a dedicated resource of professionals experienced in advising and training local authorities on major projects and programmes.
Our practice is also active advising on many outsourcing, energy and IT schemes involving local authorities.
text:
We have been advising Ministerial Departments and Executive Agencies as well as local authorities, NHS Trusts, Universities, Registered Providers and Academy Trusts throughout the UK for decades, with focus spanning across high profile, strategically important government projects, defence and security, regeneration, health, education, PFI/PPP, transport, energy, pensions and employment, general commercial and IT.

Our full commercial service, includes all aspects of public law including procurement, powers or vires and subsidy control, acting on schemes and projects of all types, including joint ventures, development schemes, service contracts and outsourcing arrangements.

We understand both the legal framework within which the public sector operates, and the high level of political scrutiny which is applied to the decisions public sector bodies make. We know how this impacts on the legal advice required. Our work fully always embraces the need to demonstrate value for money, transparency and statutory compliance.

We know that contract terms and our advice must consider the wider strategic, policy and economic objectives under which our public sector clients operate.

Our agile Central Government and Public Sector teams work from offices across the UK, combining true national reach with local roots.

Our Local Government team are a dedicated resource of professionals experienced in advising and training local authorities on major projects and programmes.

With members of our team having worked in-house as local authority lawyers, we understand the many sensitivities and complexities of local government and make ourselves available for informal discussions or to act as a sounding board for new ideas. The team are experienced in advising on general local government law issues including:

Joint committees and powers

Procurement

Local authority finance and governance

Joint venture and incremental partnership structures

Property portfolios (local asset-based vehicles)

Regeneration and social housing

Infrastructure

Waste

Education

Outsourcing

Technology projects

We have acted for local government in across a wide range of assignments including in the housing, care, education, regeneration or construction, street lighting, real estate, car parking, ICT and broadband and FM sectors. Our practice is also active advising on many outsourcing, energy and IT schemes involving local authorities.

On the contentious side, we have acted on major construction and procurement disputes and our leading procurement practice is highly valued by our local government clients.

title: DHL Express, Landmark Group partner to cut supply-chain emissions - Logistics Middle East
description:
DHL Express has signed a strategic sustainability agreement with Landmark Group to accelerate decarbonisation across regional air freight networks, marking one of the UAE’s most significant retail-logistics collaborations to date.
Under the partnership, Landmark Group will adopt DHL’s GoGreen Plus programme to reduce Scope 3 emissions across its international shipments using Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).
SAF deployment brings measurable reductions The agreement was formalised in Dubai by Mahmoud Haj Hussein, Country Manager of DHL Express UAE, and Rajesh Garg, Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Sustainability Officer at Landmark Group.
DHL and Landmark said SAF adoption provides one of the most immediate and scalable pathways to lower-carbon logistics.
DHL Express has intensified its regional decarbonisation efforts in line with DHL Group’s target to achieve net-zero emissions logistics by 2050.
text:
DHL Express has signed a strategic sustainability agreement with Landmark Group to accelerate decarbonisation across regional air freight networks, marking one of the UAE’s most significant retail-logistics collaborations to date.

Under the partnership, Landmark Group will adopt DHL’s GoGreen Plus programme to reduce Scope 3 emissions across its international shipments using Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).

The Group operates more than 2,200 retail stores across 21 countries and employs over 50,000 people, giving the agreement wide regional impact.

GoGreen Plus shifts away from traditional carbon-offsetting models by replacing fossil-based jet fuel with SAF produced from renewable feedstocks.

Each tonne of SAF used can cut lifecycle emissions by up to 80%, with reductions independently verified and certified by SGS for full accountability.

SAF deployment brings measurable reductions

The agreement was formalised in Dubai by Mahmoud Haj Hussein, Country Manager of DHL Express UAE, and Rajesh Garg, Group Chief Financial Officer and Chief Sustainability Officer at Landmark Group.

Haj Hussein said that “DHL has committed to investing €7 billion globally in climate-neutral logistics by 2030, and partnerships like this demonstrate how we’re translating that ambition into measurable action,”

Adding, “Landmark Group’s decision to adopt GoGreen Plus reflects how progressive enterprises are keen on moving the industry toward a net-zero future.”

Garg said the partnership embeds sustainability deeper into the Group’s regional logistics footprint. “Our partnership with DHL marks an important step in reducing our Scope 3 emissions and advancing our decarbonisation goals through credible solutions like Sustainable Aviation Fuel.”

Alignment with UAE Net Zero 2050

The collaboration supports the UAE’s national Net Zero 2050 strategy, which positions the country as a global leader in climate action and sustainable economic development.

Scope 3 emissions, often the largest and most complex to address, remain the primary challenge for retail supply chains. DHL and Landmark said SAF adoption provides one of the most immediate and scalable pathways to lower-carbon logistics.

DHL Express has intensified its regional decarbonisation efforts in line with DHL Group’s target to achieve net-zero emissions logistics by 2050. With demand for low-carbon freight continuing to rise, the company said it expects more regional enterprises to shift toward SAF-enabled solutions in the year ahead.

title: Emirates and ENOC Group sign MoU to explore SAF supply in Dubai - Biofuels International
description:
Emirates and ENOC Group have announced the signing of a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to explore and develop joint initiatives for the supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to Emirates at its Dubai hub.
The MoU was signed on the sidelines of the Dubai Airshow by Adel Al Redha, Emirates’ Deputy President and Chief Operating Officer and Hussain Sultan Lootah, Acting CEO of ENOC Group.
The MoU creates a framework for feasibility studies to assess SAF supply opportunities in Dubai, including supply chain infrastructure, production capabilities, and commercial viability.
The collaboration aims to explore pathways for developing economically feasible SAF production and supply infrastructure in Dubai, with ENOC evaluating its potential contribution to local production.
“Establishing reliable SAF supply in our Dubai hub is a key priority, and this collaboration allows us to assess the most viable pathways for integration.
text:
Emirates and ENOC Group have announced the signing of a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to explore and develop joint initiatives for the supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to Emirates at its Dubai hub.

The MoU was signed on the sidelines of the Dubai Airshow by Adel Al Redha, Emirates’ Deputy President and Chief Operating Officer and Hussain Sultan Lootah, Acting CEO of ENOC Group.

The MoU creates a framework for feasibility studies to assess SAF supply opportunities in Dubai, including supply chain infrastructure, production capabilities, and commercial viability.

The collaboration aims to explore pathways for developing economically feasible SAF production and supply infrastructure in Dubai, with ENOC evaluating its potential contribution to local production. A joint steering committee will guide the evaluation.

Adel Al Redha, Deputy President and Chief Operating Officer said: “Emirates continues to explore ways to integrate sustainable aviation fuel adoption in our operations, and this partnership with ENOC represents an important step in that journey.

“Establishing reliable SAF supply in our Dubai hub is a key priority, and this collaboration allows us to assess the most viable pathways for integration. We recognise there's significant work ahead to address supply constraints and infrastructure requirements, but partnerships like this are essential to identifying practical solutions and building the foundation for broader SAF accessibility in Dubai and eventually across our network."

title: AAPA says Singapore's SAF levy serves as a needed push for sustainable aviation
description:
The Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) has described Singapore’s upcoming sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) levy as an important push to encourage greater production and use of cleaner fuels in aviation, reports New Straits Times.
AAPA director general Subhas Menon said the levy is designed to motivate action, noting that travellers often express support for sustainability but do not always follow through.
The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore announced on November 10 that the SAF levy will apply to tickets sold from April 1, 2026, for flights departing Singapore from October 1, 2026.
He described Singapore’s model as a combination of firm government commitment and public willingness to support sustainability.
Beyond sustainability, Subhas urged governments to take a more active role in strengthening the region’s aviation supply chain.
text:
The Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) has described Singapore’s upcoming sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) levy as an important push to encourage greater production and use of cleaner fuels in aviation, reports New Straits Times.

AAPA director general Subhas Menon said the levy is designed to motivate action, noting that travellers often express support for sustainability but do not always follow through.

He said many passengers claim they are willing to contribute to sustainability efforts, including supporting SAF, but often “words and actions do not match,” and the levy acts as the needed reminder.

According to him, most travellers are unlikely to object to paying between S$1 and S$41—depending on destination and travel class—because the money supports a meaningful cause.

The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore announced on November 10 that the SAF levy will apply to tickets sold from April 1, 2026, for flights departing Singapore from October 1, 2026. Charges will vary by distance and cabin class.

Subhas said Singapore has also assured the public that their contributions will be used properly. The levy will go directly toward the purchase of SAF, managed by the newly established Singapore Sustainable Aviation Fuel Co Ltd. (SAFCo), which will handle procurement on behalf of the country.

He described Singapore’s model as a combination of firm government commitment and public willingness to support sustainability.

While the levy has drawn widespread attention, Subhas said it is unlikely that other Asia-Pacific countries will adopt a similar approach, as each government has different needs and policy structures.

“There is no one-size-fits-all,” he said, noting that countries are taking different pathways to increase SAF use.

Japan, for instance, is pursuing a public–private partnership model supported by its large supply of used cooking oil, creating new income opportunities for communities involved in collecting and processing it.

Malaysia, he added, has also laid out long-term plans to build domestic SAF production capacity, targeting significant output by 2050.

Subhas said most Asia-Pacific countries already have policies and regulations in place to expand SAF use, with the region now showing much faster progress than two years ago. He said these efforts are expected to lead to at least five percent SAF usage across the region.

Beyond sustainability, Subhas urged governments to take a more active role in strengthening the region’s aviation supply chain. He said airlines have repeatedly been called upon to push the sector forward, but governments also need to recognise aviation as a long-term economic opportunity worthy of investment.

He said governments can help local companies become regional suppliers of aircraft components—similar to efforts underway in China—and support investments in maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) facilities and the broader aviation aftermarket.

On rising concerns over passengers carrying lithium-ion batteries, Subhas said airlines face challenges because different countries follow different rules, causing confusion among travellers.

He noted that some airlines believe no action is needed, while others want clearer guidelines. However, he stressed that regulators—not airlines—should issue the necessary rules.

He added that if regulators do not act, the association is willing to propose recommendations based on established safety procedures.

title: Pacific Inter-Link joins DHL's GoGreen Plus programme to cut emissions with sustainable ...
description:
(PIL) has partnered with DHL Express through the GoGreen Plus programme to lower the carbon footprint of its time-definite international shipments by using sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
By joining GoGreen Plus, it is also addressing Scope 3 emissions, which include indirect emissions from supply chain activities.
Sustainable aviation fuel, produced from materials such as used cooking oil and other waste, can reduce lifecycle emissions by up to 80% compared to traditional jet fuel.
Launched in 2023, GoGreen Plus is backed by SAF contracts with partners including BP, Neste, Cosmo Energy and the Cathay Group.
Air freight represents about 70% of DHL Group’s carbon footprint, making sustainable air-transport solutions essential to reducing emissions in the logistics sector.
text:
Pacific Inter-Link Sdn. Bhd. (PIL) has partnered with DHL Express through the GoGreen Plus programme to lower the carbon footprint of its time-definite international shipments by using sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The initiative is expected to reduce emissions by up to 90%, supporting PIL’s long-term sustainability goals, reports Business Today.

Sriram Iyer, Chief Operating Officer of PIL, said SAF offers strong potential to advance climate targets while meeting the needs of air freight. He noted that as the push toward net-zero gains speed, renewable fuels provide a clear route to reducing emissions and the partnership with DHL reflects PIL’s commitment to greener operations and better carbon performance.

PIL, a global player in the edible oil and consumer goods industry, already manages its Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions according to the GHG Protocol. By joining GoGreen Plus, it is also addressing Scope 3 emissions, which include indirect emissions from supply chain activities.

Sustainable aviation fuel, produced from materials such as used cooking oil and other waste, can reduce lifecycle emissions by up to 80% compared to traditional jet fuel. DHL’s GoGreen Plus programme uses a book-and-claim model, allowing the environmental benefits of SAF to be credited to customers even when their shipments are not physically transported using SAF.

Julian Neo, Managing Director of DHL Express Malaysia and Brunei, said the company is pleased to have Pacific Inter-Link join the programme and help build wider acceptance of SAF as an important tool for lowering aviation emissions.

He added that both companies are taking key steps to scale the technology and speed up the shift toward solutions that can cut emissions across logistics operations, while continuing efforts to improve SAF production, supply and availability.

Launched in 2023, GoGreen Plus is backed by SAF contracts with partners including BP, Neste, Cosmo Energy and the Cathay Group. Air freight represents about 70% of DHL Group’s carbon footprint, making sustainable air-transport solutions essential to reducing emissions in the logistics sector.

title: Velocys Partners with ASAFA to Advance Proven Fischer–Tropsch Pathways for Asia's SAF Future
description:
Singapore, November 25, 2025 — The Asian Sustainable Aviation Fuel Association (ASAFA) is pleased to welcome Velocys, a global leader in Fischer–Tropsch (FT) technology for sustainable fuels, as its newest member.
Velocys joins ASAFA’s growing network of government, industry, and academic stakeholders working to accelerate the deployment of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) across the Asia-Pacific region.
“We are delighted to welcome Velocys to ASAFA,” said Fabrice Espinosa, CEO of ASAFA.
“Asia is one of the most dynamic regions for SAF growth,” said Matthew Viergutz, CEO of Velocys.
About Velocys Velocys is a leading licensor of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis technology.
text:
Singapore, November 25, 2025 — The Asian Sustainable Aviation Fuel Association (ASAFA) is pleased to welcome Velocys, a global leader in Fischer–Tropsch (FT) technology for sustainable fuels, as its newest member.

Velocys joins ASAFA’s growing network of government, industry, and academic stakeholders working to accelerate the deployment of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) across the Asia-Pacific region.

With a proven record in converting biogenic and waste carbon into drop-in renewable fuels, Velocys brings more than two decades of real-world FT experience to the association. Its technology has been demonstrated in multiple international projects, including Japan’s first commercial flight powered by woody biomass-to-SAF, underscoring the company’s ability to bridge feedstock diversity with reliable, bankable performance.

“We are delighted to welcome Velocys to ASAFA,” said Fabrice Espinosa, CEO of ASAFA. “As a pioneer in Fischer–Tropsch technology with demonstrated sustainable fuel production from biomass and waste, Velocys will bring valuable expertise to our mission of accelerating aviation decarbonization in Asia.”

Velocys’ compact, modular reactors are enabling SAF developers and engineering, procurement, and constructions (EPC) partners worldwide to de-risk scale-up, enhance carbon efficiency, and meet the growing demand for certified renewable jet fuels aligned with regional carbon reduction targets.

“Asia is one of the most dynamic regions for SAF growth,” said Matthew Viergutz, CEO of Velocys. “We’re proud to join ASAFA’s collaborative platform and share our technical experience in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. Projects in the region are maturing quickly. We strongly believe that SAF production in Asia is scalable, sustainable, and ready for market integration.”

Velocys’ participation in ASAFA further underscores its commitment to global SAF commercialization, complementing ongoing partnerships and demonstration projects in the Americas, Europe, and Japan.

About Velocys

Velocys is a leading licensor of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis technology. Its microFTL™ solution combines Oxford-engineered catalyst, microchannel reactor technology, and 20 years of FT knowledge built on over 13,000 hours of operation time and over 6,000 hours of commercial-scale sustainable fuel production. The company specializes in improving production efficiency and plant economics through its proprietary FT solution to help make SAF and e-fuels projects commercially viable on a global scale.

Learn more at www.velocys.com.

title: Renewable Fuel Strategy outlines path to domestic SAF industry - Infrastructure Magazine
description:
The release of the NSW Renewable Fuel Strategy represents a major step towards establishing a domestic sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) industry and strengthening Australia’s fuel security.
Sydney Airport CEO, Scott Charlton, said that Sydney Airport welcomed the release of the strategy.
“The strategy’s $130 million in funding for renewable fuel production and focus on infrastructure and supply chain assessments should help channel investment into NSW,” Charlton said.
“Around 40 percent of Australia’s aviation fuel uplift occurs at Sydney Airport which makes us the natural home for SAF.
A SAF refinery co-located with the existing aviation fuel import facilities at Kurnell is a project that would cement NSW as a regional leader in SAF production.
text:
The release of the NSW Renewable Fuel Strategy represents a major step towards establishing a domestic sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) industry and strengthening Australia’s fuel security.

Sydney Airport CEO, Scott Charlton, said that Sydney Airport welcomed the release of the strategy.

“The strategy’s $130 million in funding for renewable fuel production and focus on infrastructure and supply chain assessments should help channel investment into NSW,” Charlton said.

“NSW has joined the race to become Australia’s leader on renewable fuels – we are both one of the largest producers of sustainable feedstocks like canola and the largest users of conventional aviation fuel.

“Around 40 percent of Australia’s aviation fuel uplift occurs at Sydney Airport which makes us the natural home for SAF. A SAF refinery co-located with the existing aviation fuel import facilities at Kurnell is a project that would cement NSW as a regional leader in SAF production.

“Sydney Airport commends Premier Minns and Minister Sharpe for continuing the momentum for a renewable fuels industry in NSW, and we look forward to working with the NSW Government on implementation of the strategy.”

title: Carinata cleared for aviation fuel production - Valor International - Globo
description:
Carinata, a close relative of canola and one of the most promising feedstocks for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), delivered strong results in its first year of commercial trials in Brazil.
According to Phillipp Minarelli, Nufarm Brasil’s carinata manager, the strong results reflect the profile of the producers selected for this first commercial cycle.
“We often say it’s not the producer who chooses carinata, it’s carinata that chooses the producer,” he said.
In October, the facility conducted a test crush of 2,500 tonnes of carinata, producing both oil and meal.
Unlike canola oil, carinata oil is toxic for human consumption, requiring chemical treatment to remove harmful compounds.
text:
Carinata, a close relative of canola and one of the most promising feedstocks for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), delivered strong results in its first year of commercial trials in Brazil. With harvesting completed in recent weeks, yields easily surpassed initial projections, paving the way for rapid expansion.

Commercial planting covered 100,000 hectares under agreements between farmers and Australia’s Nufarm, which supplied the seeds. The company also secured firm offtake contracts with BP, which uses carinata oil at its SAF biorefineries in Europe.

In Mato Grosso do Sul, which led national planting with 10,000 hectares and has nearly finished its harvest, average yields reached 30 bags per hectare. Although one of the lowest averages among producing states, the result was well above Nufarm’s initial national estimate of 20 to 25 bags per hectare.

Carinata was planted in eight states. All Cerrado areas performed above expectations. In Mato Grosso, yields ranged from 30 to 35 bags per hectare, while in Goiás they averaged 33. Paraná posted roughly 37 bags per hectare. Harvesting is still underway in Rio Grande do Sul, the country’s second-largest producer with 7,500 hectares.

According to Phillipp Minarelli, Nufarm Brasil’s carinata manager, the strong results reflect the profile of the producers selected for this first commercial cycle. “We often say it’s not the producer who chooses carinata, it’s carinata that chooses the producer,” he said. The crop is well suited as a cover crop, planted after soybeans and corn as part of soil-conservation practices typically adopted by farmers with more advanced management systems. “These are farmers who already work to keep soil covered and take care when planting,” he said.

So far, all harvests have comfortably exceeded the breakeven point of 15 to 18 bags per hectare, Minarelli said. Compared with other potential SAF feedstocks, carinata has both lower production costs and a smaller carbon footprint. On average, each megajoule of energy produced from carinata-based SAF emits 14 grams of CO₂, compared with 68 grams from soybean-oil-based SAF, he said. The low carbon intensity will likely boost demand from aviation, a sector facing binding decarbonization targets starting in 2027.

One factor that makes carinata more sustainable than soy is its lower need for nitrogen fertilizers, the largest source of agricultural emissions. “Some farmers in Paraná applied no nitrogen at all and will still harvest 30 bags,” Minarelli said.

Carinata also generates abundant crop residue and has deep roots that improve soil aeration, benefiting the following summer soybean crop. “It makes soybean planting easier, with less diesel consumption and less soil compaction,” he said. And because it belongs to a different botanical family than oilseeds and cereals, carinata helps break pest and disease cycles in grain-producing areas, potentially reducing pesticide use.

There are advantages on the industrial side as well. Carinata seeds contain 38% to 45% oil, roughly twice the oil yield of soybeans.

The crop also stands out among winter alternatives for its resilience to extreme weather. Native to Ethiopia, carinata tolerates temperatures above 30°C and withstands frost. That resilience proved critical this year, when some winter fields endured four frost events and remained intact, while crops like wheat and sugarcane suffered yield losses.

Nufarm aims to double its planted area in Brazil by 2026 through expanded partnerships with producers.

Oil

Last year, when Nufarm conducted pilot trials, the harvested carinata had to be shipped to Belgium for processing. This season, carinata grown in Brazil will be processed domestically at a canola-crushing facility opened this year by Celena Alimentos and Grupo Camera in São Luiz Gonzaga, Rio Grande do Sul. With that, Brazil will begin exporting carinata oil.

In October, the facility conducted a test crush of 2,500 tonnes of carinata, producing both oil and meal. Unlike canola oil, carinata oil is toxic for human consumption, requiring chemical treatment to remove harmful compounds.

Laboratory analyses have already confirmed that carinata meal contains adequate protein levels for feed use. Additional testing is expected to certify the removal of toxic elements, according to Vantuir Scarantti, agricultural manager at Celena Alimentos.

Once meal viability is fully confirmed, the plant is expected to process carinata for one month each year, crushing 20,000 tonnes, while canola will be processed during the remaining 11 months. As domestic output expands, the facility could extend carinata crushing time, either by reducing canola throughput or increasing overall capacity, Scarantti said.

In the coming years, Nufarm expects Brazil’s planned SAF plants to internalize the entire production chain. By 2030, SAF production is slated to begin at the Refinaria de Petróleo Riograndense (RPR) in Rio Grande (Rio Grande do Sul), at Petrobras’s refinery in Cubatão (São Paulo), and at an OilGroup facility under development in Bacabeira (Maranhão).

title: Bell 505 Passes 700 Flight Hours Using Blended Sustainable Aviation Fuel
description:
Aviation News – Bell has announced that its Bell 505 helicopter has surpassed 700 flight hours powered by a blended Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), highlighting growing momentum toward cleaner rotorcraft operations.
The milestone results from an ongoing collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines, which partnered with Bell to test and validate SAF performance over extended use.
The program marks one of the industry’s more significant demonstrations of sustained SAF operations in light helicopters, underscoring a push toward lower-emission flight.
SAF blends reduce lifecycle carbon emissions compared with traditional jet fuel while maintaining compatibility with existing engines and airframes.
For the Bell 505, the trials confirm that the aircraft can operate efficiently and reliably using SAF without requiring modifications, offering operators a practical pathway to greener operations.
text:
Aviation News – Bell has announced that its Bell 505 helicopter has surpassed 700 flight hours powered by a blended Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), highlighting growing momentum toward cleaner rotorcraft operations.

The milestone results from an ongoing collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines, which partnered with Bell to test and validate SAF performance over extended use. The program marks one of the industry’s more significant demonstrations of sustained SAF operations in light helicopters, underscoring a push toward lower-emission flight.

SAF blends reduce lifecycle carbon emissions compared with traditional jet fuel while maintaining compatibility with existing engines and airframes. For the Bell 505, the trials confirm that the aircraft can operate efficiently and reliably using SAF without requiring modifications, offering operators a practical pathway to greener operations.

title: The Rise of Sustainable Aviation: How Green Tech is Reshaping Air Travel?
description:
Major Environmental Challenges in Air Travel At the outset, the truth is hard to ignore.
In fact, aviation contributes roughly 2-3% of global carbon emissions.
For instance, agreements like CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) aim to cap emissions growth.
Use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Primarily, SAF is the industry’s current favorite.
In fact, airlines work with predictive analytics to optimize flight paths, reduce drag, and save fuel.
text:
In aviation, it has always been about speed and global connectivity. Now, it is about responsibility too. Also, the sky is more complex than it looks. Essentially, every flight leaves a carbon footprint that sticks around for decades.

Also, sustainability is no longer a trend. Rather, it is a necessity. Moreover, airlines are under pressure, governments are setting targets, and passengers are asking questions.

Now, the conversation has shifted from “Is it possible fly cheaper?” to “It is possible to fly cleaner?” That shift is reshaping the entire industry.

Major Environmental Challenges in Air Travel

At the outset, the truth is hard to ignore. In fact, aviation contributes roughly 2-3% of global carbon emissions. Interestingly, that number is climbing.

It is not just CO₂ but even nitrogen oxides, contrails, and water vapor that amplify the warming effect. Also, the sector’s growth exacerbates this. More planes, more routes, more fuel burned.

Unlike cars, planes cannot just switch to electric overnight. The physics of flight make decarbonization a tough nut to crack. And while other industries have clear roadmaps, aviation’s path is full of technical and financial hurdles.

Major Reasons Why Carbon-Neutral Flights Are Necessary?

Presently, airlines are trying to clean up their act. Carbon offset programs are everywhere now. You book a ticket, and they promise to plant trees or fund renewable projects. Although it sounds good, critics still call it a band-aid solution.

In fact, offsets do not eliminate emissions. Rather, they just compensate for them. Still, it is a good start as some carriers are pledging to reach net zero by 2050. Although it is ambitious, it is actually the sole option left.

International Regulations and Agreements: What Are They Doing?

Global rules matter here. For instance, agreements like CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) aim to cap emissions growth. As a result, the following happens:

Countries sign up

Airlines comply

Basically, the idea is to keep aviation from spiraling out of control.

However, enforcement is still complicated. This is because every nation does not play fair, and loopholes exist. Meanwhile, regulations have the capability to bring in innovation. Also, they slow things down if they are too rigid. In fact, it is a balancing act of progress versus practicality.

Innovations Driving Change

This is where things get interesting. Essentially, technology is rewriting the future. Also, engineers are chasing ideas that sounded like science fiction a decade ago.

1. Electric and Hybrid Aircraft Technology

Nowadays, electric planes are no longer mere sketches. In fact, companies like Eviation and Airbus are testing prototypes for short-haul flights. Moreover, batteries are the bottleneck because they are too heavy and still lack sufficient energy density.

Meanwhile, hybrids come with a compromise, as they combine conventional engines with electric systems to reduce fuel consumption. This is how progress actually happens. For example, imagine boarding a plane that hums instead of roars. That is the dream for many.

2. Use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF)

Primarily, SAF is the industry’s current favorite. It is made from waste oils, biomass, and even algae. Also, it can slash lifecycle emissions by up to 80%. Moreover, airlines are blending SAF with traditional jet fuel, and airports are slowly adapting.

However, cost is a major factor here. SAF is expensive, and scaling production is a headache. But if you’ve ever wondered how these innovations work and thought, “write my assignment on sustainable aviation,” you are not alone—this topic is gaining academic interest.

3. Fuel Efficiency Is Possible Through AI and Data Analytics

Obviously, AI is not merely for chatbots. In fact, airlines work with predictive analytics to optimize flight paths, reduce drag, and save fuel.

Moreover, real-time data crunching means fewer wasted miles and smarter maintenance schedules. However, passengers do not see it, but the impact is real. These come in the form of:

Lower emissions

Lower costs

Fewer delays

Although this is invisible innovation, it still matters in the long run.

Challenges and Opportunities

No one talks about how expensive going green is. That is why airlines operate on thin margins. Also, new tech demands big investments. Hence, passengers might feel the pinch too. Moreover, ticket prices could rise as carriers absorb costs. This is because infrastructure is another hurdle.

In addition, airports require charging stations for electric planes, storage for SAF, and systems to handle new logistics. However, there are many opportunities. In fact, if you are an early adopter, you will be able to grab market share. Also, governments will come up with jobs in green tech. As a result, the planet gets a breather.

The following are some of the major friction points in sustainable aviation:

Cost implications. SAF and electric tech are not cheap.

Infrastructure readiness. Airports require major upgrades.

Regulatory complexity: It is difficult to work in compliance with global standards.

Even though there are many challenges, the upside is clear. Basically, cleaner skies mean a stronger brand image for airlines and better compliance with climate goals. Also, you will have a future where flying does not feel like an environmental crime.

Closing Thoughts

Now, sustainable aviation is no longer a dream. Rather, it has become a necessity. Of course, the industry is slowly but surely pivoting toward a future. Hence, flying does not mean frying the planet.

Moreover, expect tech to lead the charge. However, collaboration is necessary between airlines, regulators, and passengers. These factors will actually seal the deal. Although the skies might look the same, the engines powering them will tell a different story.

title: Bell 505 Achieves Over 700 Flight Hours with Blended Sustainable Aviation Fuel
description:

(NYSE: TXT) company, announced during European Rotors 2025 that a single, dedicated Bell 505 has surpassed 700 flight hours using blended sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), a key milestone that showcases Bell’s commitment to SAF usage and builds on its sustainability practices in its flight operations.

text:
In collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines, Bell shares long-term success with using SAF on the Bell 505

Cologne, Germany (November 24, 2025) - Bell Textron Inc., a Textron Inc. (NYSE: TXT) company, announced during European Rotors 2025 that a single, dedicated Bell 505 has surpassed 700 flight hours using blended sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), a key milestone that showcases Bell’s commitment to SAF usage and builds on its sustainability practices in its flight operations.

“Bell is proud to celebrate this next step in industry carbon reduction objectives,” said Robin Wendling, Managing Director of Europe, Bell. “Working alongside Safran Helicopter Engines has given us the cutting-edge advantage of exploring opportunities in greener aviation practices.”

In March 2022, Bell announced its collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines to explore technical performance and economic impacts of sustainable aviation fuel on the Bell 505 powered by the Arrius 2R engine. Nearly one year after the announcement, the Bell 505 became the first-ever single engine helicopter to fly with 100% SAF during a demonstration flight. Since July 2022, Bell has accumulated over 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 helicopter at the Bell Training Academy. Assessments of engine operability and aircraft performance as well as engine inspections have yielded positive results to date.

Jean-François Sauer, Safran Helicopter Engines, EVP Programs, commented, “We are particularly pleased with these SAF flights in partnership with Bell. SAF is key towards more sustainable helicopter use. The Arrius 2R, like all our engines, are currently able to operate with up to 50% drop-in SAF. Very soon, our engines will be capable of 100% drop-in SAF, paving the way for wider use of this type of fuel for increased sustainability of helicopter operations.”

Combining its Safran Arrius 2R engine, dual channel FADEC, and Garmin G1000H NXi all-glass avionics suite with a moving map display – the Bell 505 is one of the most technologically advanced platforms in its class. The added benefit of wide panoramic windows, open cabin design, and Synthetic Vision technology has classified this five-seater aircraft as an ideal platform for a variety of missions, including public safety, utility, and military training.

###

Press Contact

Bell

Gianna Messina

+1 682 219 3532

mediarelations@bh.com

Online Media Kit

Follow Us: Facebook | Twitter | LinkedIn | Instagram |YouTube

ABOUT BELL

Thinking above and beyond is what we do. For more than 90 years, we’ve been reimagining the experience of flight – and where it can take us.

We are pioneers. We were the first to break the sound barrier and to certify a commercial helicopter. We were a part of NASA’s first lunar mission and brought advanced tiltrotor systems to market. Today, we’re defining the future of advanced air mobility.

Headquartered in Fort Worth, Texas – as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Textron Inc., – we have strategic locations around the globe. And with nearly one quarter of our workforce having served, helping our military achieve their missions is a passion of ours.

Above all, our breakthrough innovations deliver exceptional experiences to our customers. Efficiently. Reliably. And always, with safety at the forefront.

ABOUT TEXTRON INC.

Textron Inc. is a multi-industry company that leverages its global network of aircraft, defense, industrial and finance businesses to provide customers with innovative solutions and services. Textron is known around the world for its powerful brands such as Bell, Cessna, Beechcraft, Pipistrel, Jacobsen, Kautex, Lycoming, E-Z-GO, and Textron Systems. For more information, visit: www.textron.com.
